text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Renewable Energy Is Surging. The G.O.P. Tax Bill Could Curtail That.
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican tax bills moving through Congress could significantly hobble the United States’ renewable energy industry because of a series of provisions that scale back incentives for wind and solar power while bolstering older energy sources like oil and gas production.

headline: Global Regulators Agree on Rules to Prevent Financial Crises
text: The world took a significant step toward averting future financial meltdowns Thursday, just as the United States under President Trump begins relaxing constraints on risky behavior by banks.

headline: House Republican Trent Franks Resigns Amid Harassment Investigation
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Trent Franks of Arizona, one of the House’s most ardent social conservatives, said Thursday night that he would resign after the House Ethics Committee began an investigation into complaints that he had asked two female staff members to be a surrogate to bear his child.

headline: Bela, the Forgotten War Orphan
text: Bela Raphael Simons’s first steps at LaGuardia Field in 1946 were documented by a crowd of photographers watching her every move as she met her adoptive mother, Jeanne Simons. Jeanne’s husband, Bert, an army sergeant stationed in occupied Berlin, had spent months after World War II battling to bring Bela to the United States. Her arrival in New York appeared to be a happy ending for a child whose biological parents had been killed in Auschwitz.

headline: Hearing Denied for Yoga Teacher Convicted in Dancer’s 2005 Killing
text: An effort to win a new trial for a yoga teacher convicted of slashing the throat of a young dancer from Ohio in 2005 ran into a wall on Thursday when a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan denied a request for a hearing.

headline: 8 Highlights From Miami Art Week
text: With more than 20 fairs, countless parties and several off-site installations to explore, Miami Art Week is not for the faint of heart. This year, with the opening of ICA Miami, the relaunch of the Bass and Studio Drift’s fleet of 300 drones flying by night, the whole spectacle felt as saturated as ever. Here, your guide on what not to miss — or, if you’re not making the trip, the things to know about — in Miami.

headline: Nearly Every Former U.S. Ambassador to Israel Disagrees With Trump’s Jerusalem Decision
text: All but two of 11 former United States ambassadors to Israel contacted by The New York Times after President Trump’s decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s capital thought the plan was wrongheaded, dangerous or deeply flawed.

headline: Citigroup’s $20 Billion Write-Down Would Be Just the Ticket
text: A $20 billion accounting loss can be a good thing, when the company in question is Citigroup. The lender’s woes during the financial crisis a decade ago helped make “write-down” a household word. Now the $200 billion colossus may take another whopping great hit. But this time the potential loss, sparked by planned tax cuts, is actually pretty helpful.

headline: Bill Steinkraus, Equestrian Who Made Olympic History, Dies at 92
text: Bill Steinkraus, one of America’s most celebrated horse-show riders and the country’s first to win an Olympic individual gold medal in any equestrian discipline, died on Nov. 29 at his home in the Noroton section of Darien, Conn. He was 92.

headline: Goff and Wentz, Top 2 Picks in 2016, Will Finally Meet on the Field
text: Just a year and a half ago, Jared Goff and Carson Wentz were taken first and second in the N.F.L. draft. But which one has turned out to be Peyton Manning and which one Ryan Leaf?

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: Muhammad Ali, Julia Child and Leonardo da Vinci are three big names anchoring this week’s list of recommendations. The first full biography since Ali’s death last year tells the story of his epic life; “France Is a Feast” shows off Paul Child’s accomplished photos of Julia Child and postwar Paris; and Walter Isaacson’s latest best seller considers the awe-inspiring work of the Renaissance man. A diverse assortment of other subjects this week includes cleaning up surgery, survival in the jungle, food’s role in the British Empire and the life of an endangered animal.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Lena Dunham, Her Main Millennial, Hit the Weinstein Wall
text: From the start, Lena Dunham and Hillary Clinton were something of an odd match. The millennial daughter of New York privilege known for her audacious public presence and frequent nudity on her HBO show, “Girls.” And the baby boomer raised with a steely Midwestern reserve, a devotion to her Methodist faith and a fierce affinity for a “zone of privacy.”

headline: Perry Wallace, College Basketball Pioneer, Is Dead at 69
text: Perry Wallace, who became the first black varsity basketball player in Southeastern Conference history in the 1960s as a strong-rebounding forward for his hometown Vanderbilt University in Nashville, died on Dec. 1 at a hospice in Rockville, Md. He was 69.

headline: Les Whitten, Muckraking Columnist and Novelist, Dies at 89
text: Les Whitten, who shared a byline with Jack Anderson on a nationally syndicated newspaper column that mercilessly exposed Washington’s foibles and frauds and who once even spied on J. Edgar Hoover, the director of the F.B.I., died on Saturday in Adelphi, Md. He was 89.

headline: Trump Orders U.S. Embassy Move from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem
text: President Trump on Wednesday formally recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, breaking with nearly 70 years of American foreign policy and with the international community, setting in motion a plan to move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

headline: The Republican War on Children
text: Let me ask you a question; take your time in answering it. Would you be willing to take health care away from a thousand children with the bad luck to have been born into low-income families so that you could give millions of extra dollars to just one wealthy heir?

headline: New York City Planned to Put 400 Teachers in Jobs. It’s Placed 41.
text: Earlier this year, New York City’s Department of Education announced that it would place roughly 400 teachers who had been caught in a kind of educational limbo — without full-time jobs but getting paid — in classrooms full time.

headline: Fewer Russians Could Be a Windfall for U.S. Olympic Business
text: In the wake of Tuesday’s International Olympic Committee decision to ban the Russian team from the Winter Games in South Korea in February, many assumed companies that have invested in the Games would take a serious financial hit.

headline: ‘Unlawful Conspiracy’ Keeps Out Rival Builders in Edgewater, Suit Claims
text: In the latest indication that real estate can be a bloody, full-contact sport, the borough of Edgewater, N.J., and developers are trading body blows over one of the last large waterfront sites left on New Jersey’s Gold Coast.

headline: Saudi Crown Prince Was Behind Record Bid for a Leonardo
text: LONDON — Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, acting through a friend and distant cousin, was the true buyer behind the purchase of Leonardo da Vinci’s “Salvator Mundi” for a record-breaking $450.3 million, American officials and an Arab familiar with the arrangement said Thursday.

headline: Ex-Governor’s Run Gives Democrats a Bit More Hope of Retaking the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Former Gov. Phil Bredesen, the last Democrat to win statewide office in Tennessee, announced on Thursday that he would run for the seat being vacated by Senator Bob Corker, handing his party a conceivable, if extremely narrow, path back to a Senate majority in 2018.

headline: Bitcoin’s Price Has Soared. What Comes Next?
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Bitcoin has been in a bull market like few the world has ever seen.

headline: Gymnastics Doctor Who Abused Patients Gets 60 Years for Child Pornography
text: Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar, a former team doctor for U.S.A. Gymnastics who has pleaded guilty to sexually abusing gymnasts under the guise of medical treatment, was sentenced on Thursday to 60 years in prison on child pornography charges.

headline: Elliott Management Is Said Push for Changes at Alexion
text: LONDON — Alexion Pharmaceuticals has remade its executive ranks over the past year in a bid to turn around its fortunes. But one of the biggest activist hedge funds around thinks that the company’s efforts haven’t been enough.

headline: Ford Will Build Electric Cars in Mexico, Shifting Its Plan
text: Almost a year ago, after heavy criticism from President-elect Donald J. Trump, Ford Motor Company canceled plans to build a $1.6 billion car plant in Mexico and announced that it would instead equip a Michigan factory to make electric and hybrid models.

headline: City Ballet’s Peter Martins Takes Leave of Absence After Misconduct Accusation
text: Peter Martins, who picked up the mantle from the famed choreographer George Balanchine to lead New York City Ballet over the last three decades, is taking a leave of absence in the wake of a sexual harassment accusation, the company confirmed on Thursday night.

headline: James O’Keefe, Practitioner of the Sting, Has an Ally in Trump
text: WASHINGTON — Days after Donald J. Trump launched his presidential campaign in June 2015, James O’Keefe, the conservative disrupter famous for trying to use secret recordings to embarrass liberals and journalists, visited Trump Tower and gave Mr. Trump a preview of his latest hidden camera video intended to undermine Hillary Clinton.

headline: Please Save Kids’ Health Care
text: Nearly nine million children across the country receive health care services through the Children’s Health Insurance Program, enacted with bipartisan congressional support in 1997 to provide health care coverage for children from eligible families with low and moderate incomes. In our four states — Massachusetts, Montana, Nevada and Oregon — more than 300,000 children rely on the program, known as CHIP. But any day now, if Congress doesn’t act, these kids could lose the health care they depend on.

headline: Online Shopping: Disrupting Retail, and Drivers’ Lives
text: At lunchtime Thursday, Miguel Lopez paused on his rounds in Elmhurst, Queens. He got hired part-time for United Parcel Service when he was 23. That was two decades ago. A small start-up mail order company called Amazon was then in its early days selling books online, a blip that became a behemoth. The part-time job has ballooned so much that what is part-time is his life outside work.

headline: Quotation of the Day: White Officer Who Shot Black Man in the Back Is Sentenced to 20 Years
text: “I forgive you, and I pray for you that you will repent and let Jesus come into your life. Just as you are, he will forgive you.”

headline: California’s Fires, by the Numbers
text: Just one of the fires raging in Southern California has already burned an area larger than Detroit, fueled by winds nearing hurricane strength. Here’s a look at the numbers behind the state’s worst fire season ever.

headline: Devin Nunes Cleared of Misconduct Over Disclosing Monitoring of Trump Aides
text: WASHINGTON — A congressional ethics panel cleared Representative Devin Nunes, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, on Thursday of wrongdoing related to accusations that he improperly disclosed classified information.

headline: Did Trump Kill Off a Two-State Solution? He Says No, Palestinians Say Yes
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump, in formally recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel on Wednesday, declared that the United States still supported a two-state solution to settle the conflict between the Israelis and Palestinians, provided it was “agreed to by both sides.”

headline: Along Mulholland Drive in Los Angeles, Unsettling Feelings to Go With the Scenery
text: LOS ANGELES — From where Marco Alvarez sat in his car alongside Mulholland Drive on Thursday, nothing seemed right.

headline: Teaching Japanese-American Internment Using Primary Resources
text: The day after the early-morning surprise assault on Pearl Harbor, on Dec. 7, 1941, the United States formally declared war on Japan and entered World War II. Over the next few months, almost 120,000 people of Japanese ancestry, over 60 percent of whom were American citizens, were removed from their homes, businesses and farms on the West Coast and forced to live in internment camps. Why? The United States government feared that these individuals, simply because of their ethnicity, posed a national security threat.

headline: The Trump Administration’s Coal Bailout
text: Federal energy regulators will soon vote on a ham-fisted Trump administration proposal to subsidize coal-fired power plants. This plan could cost families and businesses billions of dollars in higher electricity prices for no discernible public benefit.

headline: Documentaries About Doping and Jane Goodall Make Oscar Shortlist
text: The Russian doping scandal, the environment and the primatologist Jane Goodall are among the subjects of the 15 films on the shortlist for the Oscar for best documentary feature unveiled on Thursday.

headline: The G.O.P. Is Rotting
text: A lot of good, honorable Republicans used to believe there was a safe middle ground. You didn’t have to tie yourself hip to hip with Donald Trump, but you didn’t have to go all the way to the other extreme and commit political suicide like the dissident Jeff Flake, either. You could sort of float along in the middle, and keep your head down until this whole Trump thing passed.

headline: Al Franken’s Improbable Political Rise and Sudden Fall
text: WASHINGTON — Al Franken walked onto the Senate floor just before noon Thursday and anxiously scanned the spectator galleries above to find his family. He wanted to make sure they were there in what was going to be the most difficult moment in a short but — until recent days — wildly successful political career.

headline: What Congress Can Learn from Al Franken
text: In a different era — say, three months ago — Senator Al Franken could have denied the accusations of sexual misconduct against him, relied on the notoriously plodding Senate Ethics Committee to investigate him and, in the end, probably kept his job.

headline: Congressional Democrats Left Out of White House Hanukkah Party
text: WASHINGTON — The latkes were fried and the kosher lamb chops were prepared on Thursday, just as in past years, for the first White House Hanukkah party of the Trump era. But there was one prominent break with tradition: President Trump did not invite Democratic lawmakers.

headline: Jahlil Okafor Headed to Nets in Trade With 76ers
text: Jahlil Okafor, a former N.B.A. lottery pick who had fallen out of favor with the Philadelphia 76ers — and completely out of their rotation — will get a fresh opportunity with the Nets, who acquired him Thursday in a trade with the 76ers.

headline: On Tax Bill, It’s Trump vs. His Hometown
text: When President Trump returned to his hometown on Saturday for a day of fund-raisers, his third and final check-collecting stop was the Park Avenue home of Stephen A. Schwarzman, where the crowd included some of Mr. Trump’s old New York friends and real estate colleagues.

headline: Using New Regimen, Noah Syndergaard Says He Has ‘Never Felt Better’
text: A handful of Mets players were in town on Thursday to help host the team’s annual holiday party. Outfielder Brandon Nimmo dressed up as Santa Claus, while starter Noah Syndergaard, reliever Jerry Blevins and catcher Kevin Plawecki were his elves, handing out toys to schoolchildren at Citi Field.

headline: New Trailer: ‘Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom’ With Chris Pratt
text: “I know why we’re here,” the dinosaur trainer Owen Grady (Chris Pratt) tells former park manager Claire Dearing (Bryce Dallas Howard) in the new trailer for “Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom.” It’s not just because the film’s 2015 predecessor grossed more than $1.6 billion worldwide. As Mr. Pratt’s character explains, they are on “a rescue op to save the dinosaurs from an island that’s about to explode. What could go wrong?”

headline: Poland Gets a New Prime Minister in Cabinet Reshuffle
text: WARSAW — Poland will get a new prime minister next week, the centerpiece of a cabinet reshuffle at the midpoint of the governing party’s four-year term. But the party’s undisputed leader, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, will retain the real behind-the-scenes power in the country’s increasingly authoritarian government.

headline: 2 Times Reporters Will Write Book on Sexual Abuse Scandals
text: The New York Times reporters Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey will publish a book about the sexual abuse and harassment scandals that have convulsed the nation over the past two months, Penguin Press confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Comment From the Smitten
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — By the time you read this, I will be toasting the passengers joining us aboard the Queen Mary 2 as part of the Times Journeys Crossword Cruise to England, and I’m very excited. It’s my first cruise, and I can’t wait to solve my way across the Atlantic with a group of fellow puzzleheads. Also, buffets. I am unnaturally excited about the buffets.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Eating Straight Out of the Fridge

I can be sitting in a different room when he opens the fridge, and it still turns my stomach. Please tell him to stop.

headline: For the Love of Christmas Lights
text: When it comes to curb appeal, I’m usually all in. By the first warm days of spring, my stoop is awash with planters brimming with begonias, marigolds and petunias. In the fall, out come the mums and the pumpkins. But by the time December rolls around, I am done. I just don’t have it in me to climb a ladder and do battle with an uncooperative string of Christmas lights.

Research your options — but avoid “maximizing,” or exhaustively considering every possibility in search of the perfect. “Focus on what’s good enough for you,” Summerville says.

headline: A Tom Clancy Fan Continues Tom Clancy’s Series
text: FAN FICTION: How long can an author’s shelf life last after his life life has ended? Since Tom Clancy’s death in 2013, at the age of 66, his publishers have drafted various writers to extend his franchise of techno-political thrillers, leading to eight new best sellers — the latest, Marc Cameron’s “Tom Clancy: Power and Empire,” features the recurring hero Jack Ryan and enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 7. Cameron, a retired United States marshal, has had some success with his own thrillers; “Brute Force” hit the e-book list last year. But this is his first outing as a ghostwriter for an actual ghost. “It was daunting, because these are such large characters,” he told me by phone from his home in Alaska. “I was a Clancy fan from the time I was a rookie policeman and read ‘The Hunt for Red October.’ I was 22.”

headline: What Doctors Should Ignore
text: Sickle cell anemia was first described in 1910 and was quickly labeled a “black” disease. At a time when many people were preoccupied with an imagined racial hierarchy, with whites on top, the disease was cited as evidence that people of African descent were inferior. But what of white people who presented with sickle cell anemia?

headline: Can Steve Bannon Realign American Politics?

headline: How Peter Zaharatos, Chocolate Artist, Spends His Sundays
text: Peter Zaharatos, the owner of SugarCube, a dessert and coffee shop in Long Island City, Queens, has recreated company logos, the ruins of the Greek Temple of Apollo, and the Empire State Building, all in chocolate. A violinist-turned-architect and now a chocolate artist, Mr. Zaharatos, 45, uses his 3-D printer to design chocolate molds and plates for specific desserts, complete with moats that catch drizzled syrup and fillings. He lives with his wife, Magda Menounos Zaharatos, 40, who works in marketing, and their two children, Alexandra, 4, and Nicholas, 22 months, in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

headline: Facts Have a Well-Known Liberal Bias
text: There are two central facts about 21st-century U.S. politics. First, we suffer from asymmetric polarization: the Republican Party has become an extremist institution with little respect for traditional norms of any kind. Second, mainstream media – still the source of most political information for the great majority of Americans – haven’t been able to come to grips with this reality. Even in the age of Trump, they try desperately to be “balanced”, which in practice means bending over backwards to say undeserved nice things about Republicans and take undeserved swipes at Democrats.

This and several other themes are picked up in two upcoming books by Ms. Woodson: a middle-grade novel called “The Dream of America,” and a picture book called “The Day You Begin.” They will be published in August.

headline: Berlin’s State Opera Has Served Kings, Presidents and Dictators. Now What?
text: BERLIN — Since its founding, the Berlin State Opera has lived through a monarchy, two republics and two dictatorships. It is used to strong leaders. text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations said on Friday that at least 15 peacekeepers, all from Tanzania, were killed in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo by militant extremists. It was the deadliest assault on the organization’s peacekeeping forces in nearly a quarter century.

headline: As Fighting Fades in N.H.L., Panthers’ Haley Survives on His Other Skills
text: Nearly seven years have passed since the wild night at Nassau Coliseum in February 2011 when Micheal Haley, a 24-year-old Islanders rookie called up that morning from the minor leagues, scored his first N.H.L. goal. Almost as memorable: He got into three fights that game.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
text: The feminist bimonthly magazine Bust has been around since 1993, emerging from a culture embracing riot grrrl bands and, to a lesser extent, Jane Pratt’s seminal girl-centric teenage publication Sassy. Part of Bust’s tradition — besides its downtown cultural sensibility, D.I.Y. ethos and enlightened political consciousness — is the Craftacular, a riot of music, “indie shopping” (as Bust puts it) and progressive attitude. Begun 12 years ago as a holiday event in Brooklyn, the Craftacular has expanded to other seasons, and to cities like London, Boston and Los Angeles.

headline: Kaepernick vs. the N.F.L.: A Primer on His Collusion Case
text: As protests by N.F.L. players during the national anthem seem to have settled down, the grievance case against the league by the man who started it all, the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, is proceeding.

headline: A New York Hotel That’s a Destination for Design
text: 11 Howard in Soho features sculptures and paintings, light-filled rooms and a stylish all-day lounge.

headline: At Columbia, Three Women, 30 Years and a Pattern of Harassment
text: The three stories are nearly identical. A young woman arrives at Columbia University for her doctoral studies, eager to prove herself as a scholar. A star professor’s attentions seem to indicate she has succeeded. The attentions soon turn sexual, and the student grows uncomfortable. But she feels powerless to speak out.

headline: Dylan Farrow, Woody Allen’s Accuser, Says #MeToo Movement Is ‘Selective’
text: Dylan Farrow, the adopted daughter of Woody Allen who has alleged that he sexually abused her as a child, questioned in an article published this week why Mr. Allen had escaped the consequences of the widespread social backlash that was set off by the fall of the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein.

headline: Trump Rallies a Florida Crowd in Support of an Alabama Senate Candidate
text: PENSACOLA, Fla. — President Trump’s crowd was here in Florida on Friday night, but his audience was in Alabama.

headline: In ‘Coco,’ Death Is the Point
text: You may remember the first time you saw a movie character die. There’s probably an entire generation still scarred after a stampede killed Mufasa in “The Lion King” or Little Foot’s mother died trying to save him from a Sharptooth in “The Land Before Time.” And no matter how many times I watch it, I still tear up in the first minutes of Pixar’s “Up,” when Carl loses his beloved wife.

headline: Dina Powell, Influential Foreign Policy Adviser, Is Set to Exit White House
text: WASHINGTON — Dina H. Powell, a deputy national security adviser to President Trump and one of the most influential women in the Trump administration, will step down early next year, the White House said on Friday.

headline: The One Claim That Rodchenkov, Doping Whistle-Blower, Retracts
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Various sports officials and antidoping investigators have drawn far-reaching conclusions based on the claims made by Grigory Rodchenkov, Russia’s former top sports chemist.

headline: Golden State Warriors’ Go-to Guy Doesn’t Play a Minute
text: NEW ORLEANS — Late in the fourth quarter of the Golden State Warriors’ game against the New Orleans Pelicans on Monday night, Eric Housen sensed that something was amiss as he sorted through gear in the visiting locker room at the Smoothie King Center.

headline: Jackson Had a Great Year, but Mayfield Will Win the Heisman
text: Lamar Jackson’s 2017 might have been better than his 2016.

headline: A Polite Drive for Secession in ‘Radio Free Vermont’
text: Peculiar, impractical and illegal though it may be, secession has its enthusiasts in a surprising number of states. Just last year, Texas Republicans voted on whether to include an endorsement of independence in their party platform (they didn’t); this year, there have already been three attempts in California at a “Calexit,” though it’s probably more viable as a Scrabble word than a political objective.

headline: The Playlist: Seun Kuti and Santana Sound an Alarm, and 10 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Brandi Carlile explores motherhood, Migos and Marshmello unite for a rap-rock collaboration and Chris Thile collects his tracks from “A Prairie Home Companion” into an album.

headline: Kim Davis Denied Him a Marriage License. He’s Running to Replace Her.
text: In 2015, David Ermold wanted a marriage license, but was denied by his county clerk, Kim Davis. Now he wants her job.

headline: The Next Flu Pandemic Will Appear When You Least Expect It
text: If a new flu pandemic emerges, it may be easy to spot. The epidemic is most likely to appear in spring or summer, researchers have found — not in the midwinter depths of the flu season.

headline: Everything You Wanted to Know About Baseball’s Intriguing Two-Way Player
text: It’s official: Shohei Ohtani, the so-called Babe Ruth of Japan, will take up his new life in the United States as a member of the Los Angeles Angels.

headline: ‘Big Little Lies’ to Return for a Second Season
text: “Big Little Lies” is getting a little bigger.

headline: Some Older Smokers Turn to Vaping. That May Not Be a Bad Idea.
text: Jeannie Cox currently enjoys a flavor called Coffee & Cream when she vapes. She’s also fond of White Lotus, which tastes “kind of fruity.”

headline: The Fallout From Trump’s Jerusalem Shift
text: What could go wrong in the aftermath of President Trump’s decision to formally recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.

headline: Review: ‘Brooklyn Nutcracker’ Is Simply, Imperfectly Charming
text: On Thursday, I went to “The Brooklyn Nutcracker” with a friend who grew up in Paris. A cosmopolitan balletomane, he can compare New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater not only with each other but also with the Paris Opera Ballet and other top troupes. He enjoys disagreeing with me about the relative merits of “Swan Lake” productions. Before the show, he issued strong views on the sanctity of Tchaikovsky’s score.

headline: This Judge Defends ‘Unredeemables’ Even as He Sends Them to Prison
text: It seemed routine when Judge Jack B. Weinstein issued stiff prison sentences to three young men who had robbed a family at gunpoint in the Cypress Hills Houses in East New York last year. After all, when the men broke into the family’s apartment, there were, in addition to adults, five children inside — all of them 10 years old or younger. The robbers, moreover, had been accused of working with two violent street gangs, which New York law-enforcement officers have been cracking down on — especially in the city’s public housing projects.

headline: Behind the Screams
text: See how we made our scariest-ever Great Performers issue.

headline: A Rite of Passage for a Los Angeles Mayor: A Natural Disaster
text: LOS ANGELES — There were visits to two fire sites. Meetings with firefighters at command posts, and two news conferences 15 miles apart.

headline: Fashion, Dinosaurs and Food
text: Galas were held last week for Lincoln Center, the American Museum of Natural History, and Food Allergy Research and Education.

headline: U.S. Faces Blunt Criticism at U.N. Over Jerusalem Decree
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States faced blunt and sometimes withering criticism from friends and adversaries alike at the United Nations on Friday over President Trump’s declaration that Jerusalem is Israel’s capital and his plans to move the American Embassy to the highly contested holy city.

headline: Fixing the Housing Authority in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tackling Gun Violence
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wiki, Formerly of the Hip-Hop Collective Ratking, Strikes Out on His Own
text: Patrick Morales, a.k.a. Wiki

headline: The CVS-Aetna Merger
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Second Coming of the KKK’
text: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: My Generation Thought Women Were Empowered. Did We Deceive Ourselves?
text: When I started out in journalism in the 1970s, attitudes toward sexual harassment among the token women sprinkled about in newsrooms were nearly antithetical to those we’ve heard from the women who have come forth in recent weeks with a flood of anguished revelations.

headline: Trump and the Foreign Service
text: To the Editor:

headline: Eluding Censors, a Magazine Covers Southeast Asia’s Literary Scene
text: HONG KONG — At Monument Books, a bookstore in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, the magazine racks are stacked with copies of The Economist and other titles from Britain, Australia, France and the United States.

headline: Under New Tax Plan, the Cost of Aging Could Rise
text: In the coming days, a small group of Republicans will meet in Washington to try to settle a simple question: Should their revised tax bill eliminate a deduction for medical expenses and take away thousands of dollars each year from many people who are sick and, often, old?

headline: Brazen Virtuosity: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
text: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what’s moved and delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

headline: Bobby Flay’s Recipe for Looking Tailored
text: The chef and restaurateur Bobby Flay, 52, often appears on television in his chef coat, but off screen he’s found a reliable style that’s part cozy, part tailored. It helps that he stays trim, too, which is no small feat for a chef who travels so much. His secret? Healthy cooking, of course, which is also the topic of this latest cookbook, “Bobby Flay Fit: 200 Recipes for a Healthy Lifestyle.” Here, Mr. Flay shares his recipe for fashion, including “brunch sweaters,” Filson bags and Brooklyn sneakers.

headline: Justice Dept. Investigating Fetal Tissue Transfers by Planned Parenthood and Others
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department appears to be laying the groundwork for an investigation into the transfer of fetal tissue by abortion providers, including Planned Parenthood, picking up where several Republican-led inquiries in Congress had dropped off last year.

headline: Moore Accuser Says She Wrote Part of Yearbook Inscription
text: GEORGIANA, Ala. — Four days before an Alabama Senate election with broad implications for American government, the narrow questions of whether Roy S. Moore wrote in a high school yearbook 40 years ago, and what it means for sexual misconduct allegations against him, once again took center stage on Friday.

headline: Five Days of Smoke and Fire in Southern California
text: Six major fires are burning across Southern California. They began Monday and many are still raging.

headline: Ron Meyer, Who Coached S.M.U. to a Football Title, Dies at 76
text: Ron Meyer, a college and professional football coach who guided Southern Methodist University to the 1981 Southwest Conference championship but left soon after while the team was on probation for recruiting violations, some of which he was accused of, died on Tuesday in Austin, Tex. He was 76.

headline: How We Deal With Harassment Charges
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Syria’s Skies, Close Calls With Russian Warplanes
text: AL UDEID AIR BASE, Qatar — Russian fighter jets have flown dangerously close to American warplanes in eastern Syria over the past month — including one near-collision — in what American officials say is a pattern of daily Russian violations of an agreement to separate rival forces converging on the last main pocket of Islamic State militants in the country.

headline: Songs, Music Publisher of Lorde and Diplo, Bought by Kobalt
text: In a closely watched music deal, one upstart is buying another for the rights to a catalog of fresh pop hits like Lorde’s “Royals” and the Weeknd’s “Can’t Feel My Face.”

headline: Why We ‘Hear’ Some Silent GIFs
text: This week, in an improbable turn of events, the sound of silence went viral.

headline: Dozens of Horses Killed as Fires Tear Through California
text: The fires sweeping through Southern California, destroying property and threatening human lives, have also killed at least 54 horses, according to the authorities.

headline: F.B.I. Warned Hope Hicks About Emails From Russian Operatives
text: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. officials warned one of President Trump’s top advisers, Hope Hicks, earlier this year about repeated attempts by Russian operatives to make contact with her during the presidential transition, according to people familiar with the events.

headline: Supplements Claiming to Ease Opioid Addiction Come Under Scrutiny
text: Chris Beekman, whose company sells the dietary supplement Opiate Detox Pro, does not understand what all the fuss is about.

headline: Mickey Gurdus, Who Eavesdropped on the World, Dies at 73
text: Mickey Gurdus was always a good listener.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: In 2017, Pop Music Made Triumph Out of Tough Times
text: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: Who Is Hope Hicks?
text: Ms. Hicks, President Trump’s 29-year-old communications director and one of his longest-serving advisers, has left the White House. Her departure leaves a void in Mr. Trump’s inner circle.

headline: For Female Lobbyists, Harassment Often Accompanies Access
text: Vanessa Alarid was a lobbyist in New Mexico when she asked a lawmaker over drinks one night if she could count on his support for a bill that appeared to be coming down to a single vote.

headline: With Al Franken Coming Home, Minnesotans Watch and Reel
text: MINNEAPOLIS — When Bryan Dahlmeier, a 41-year-old manager of a body shop, first heard that Senator Al Franken was accused of groping a woman, he was willing to extend him some “Minnesota Nice.”

headline: Report Into FIFA Raises Questions About Ethics Investigator
text: LISBON — The job of chief ethics investigator for the often ethically challenged FIFA has a tortured history.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
text: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Tower Planned for Upper West Side May Be Too Tall and Too Late
text: In a city seemingly exhausted by a long-running construction boom, the number of pitched battles over new developments appears to be growing.

headline: Judge Voids Loans to Impaired Players in N.F.L. Concussion Case
text: A group of former pro football players with cognitive impairment who took out tens of thousands of dollars in high-interest loans against their expected payments in the N.F.L. concussion settlement may not have to pay their lenders back.

headline: The Halifax Explosion and Au Revoir to Hi: The Canada Letter
text: While I was in Halifax this week to write about the massive explosion there 100 years ago that killed 2,000 people and injured 10,000, I went to a screening of a documentary film without a soundtrack. But I wouldn’t call it a silent movie.

headline: Clint Dempsey on His Heart, His Career and Another Chance at a Title
text: TORONTO — The tests had gone on for months, Clint Dempsey said, but the palpitations in his chest simply would not go away. They accompanied him to games and to practice, while he represented his club and then his country. Week after week, no one was able to tell him what was happening.

headline: Apple Said to Be Acquiring Shazam, the Song Identifying App
text: A decade ago, Apple’s iPhone helped make a music-tech star out of Shazam, the app that, almost like magic, could identify a song just by hearing a few seconds of it.

headline: Tillerson Criticizes Saudi Arabia, Citing Its Policies in Yemen and Lebanon
text: PARIS — The Trump administration’s infatuation with Saudi Arabia — a defining element of President Trump’s early foreign policy — is cooling.

headline: Focus on Shareholders Holds Back U.S. Wage Growth
text: Corporate America’s shareholder-first ethos is holding back wage growth. The United States economy added a healthy 228,000 jobs in November, which was more than expected, but wage growth remained tepid. President Trump claims the Republican tax bill will lead to big raises, but most companies plan to spend any profit on buybacks and dividends.

headline: Court Rules Against Brendan Dassey, Subject of ‘Making a Murderer’
text: The seesaw legal battle of Brendan Dassey, whose conviction was questioned in the Netflix documentary series “Making a Murderer,” took another turn on Friday as a federal court in Chicago ruled against him, dealing a major blow to his hopes of being freed from prison.

headline: ‘The Crown’ Season 2 Premiere: We Must Maintain the Status Quo
text: It must be hard, when you’re the queen of England, to find a true friend among all the sycophants. But it’s a safe bet that anyone who will complain to your face about the food at Buckingham Palace isn’t telling you only what you want to hear.

headline: Wildfires, Puerto Rico, Star Wars: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: This Blog, R.I.P.
text: I was apparently the first blogger for The New York Times, most recently using this “on the ground” space for my own ruminations and those of others. But this technology platform is no longer going to be maintained, and we’ve decided that the world has moved on from blogs — so this is the last post here.

headline: Justices to Hear Second Partisan Gerrymandering Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court added a second partisan gerrymandering case to its docket on Friday, suggesting that the justices are seriously considering whether voting maps warped by politics may sometimes cross a constitutional line. The court has never struck down a voting district as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander.

headline: Cuomo Administration Faces an F.B.I. Investigation Into Payroll Practices
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s hiring practices are under investigation, as F.B.I. agents and federal prosecutors have begun examining how staff members working in the governor’s office are being paid by other New York State authorities and agencies.

headline: ‘We Watched Our House Burn’: Losing It All in California’s Fires
text: In Ventura County, Jack Selby watched his childhood home burn to the ground, and Nancy Cole lost all her possessions, including family heirlooms from Holocaust survivors.

headline: CNN Corrects a Trump Story, Fueling Claims of ‘Fake News’
text: CNN on Friday corrected an erroneous report that Donald Trump Jr. had received advance notice from the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks about a trove of hacked documents that it planned to release during last year’s presidential campaign.

headline: James Levine Will Not Face Criminal Charges in Illinois
text: Law enforcement officials in Illinois said Friday that they would not bring criminal charges against the famed Metropolitan Opera conductor James Levine, noting that the man accusing Mr. Levine of sexual abuse there three decades ago had been 16 at the time — which was then the age of consent.

headline: Snow in Texas Is ‘Pretty Cool’ for Children Seeing It for the First Time
text: In his 10 years, Vincent Rivera of Corpus Christi, Tex., knew snow only as something experienced by others.

headline: Tracy Stallard, Who Gave Up Historic Maris Homer, Dies at 80
text: Tracy Stallard, who became a footnote in baseball history for throwing the pitch that the Yankees’ Roger Maris hit for his 61st home run on the last day of the 1961 season — breaking one of the game’s most cherished records, Babe Ruth’s 60-homer season for the 1927 Yankees — died on Wednesday in Kingsport, Tenn. He was 80.

headline: Leslie Wolfe, Who Pursued Equality for Women, Dies at 74
text: Leslie R. Wolfe, who pursued equality for women, particularly women of color, as a longtime leader of the Center for Women Policy Studies in Washington, died on Nov. 30 in Rockville, Md. She was 74.

headline: Saudi Arabia Disputes That Crown Prince Bought ‘Salvator Mundi’
text: LONDON — The Saudi Embassy in Washington on Friday offered a new explanation for the record-breaking $450.3 million purchase last month of a painting by Leonardo da Vinci.

headline: The Great Al Franken Moment
text: Ten years from now, do you think we’ll be talking about where we were when Al Franken announced he was resigning from the Senate?

headline: Justices, Divided 5-4, Let Trump Shield DACA Documents
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration may temporarily shield documents concerning its decision to end a program that protected some 800,000 young, undocumented immigrants from deportation, the Supreme Court ruled Friday in a brief, unsigned order. The court said it would consider the matter further, and it set an expedited briefing schedule.

headline: Shohei Ohtani’s Arrival Is a Departure for the Angels and Mike Trout
text: Even by his own high standards, Mike Trout is having a very good week. He and his fiancée, Jessica Tara Cox, are getting married on Saturday. His beloved football team, the first-place Philadelphia Eagles, is training this week at his home ballpark in Anaheim, Calif. There are even unusual weather patterns whipping around the country and Trout, an amateur storm-tracker, must be fascinated.

headline: Trent Franks, Accused of Offering $5 Million to Aide for Surrogacy, Resigns
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Trent Franks announced Friday that he would resign from Congress immediately after accusations emerged that he had offered $5 million to a female employee to be a surrogate mother for his children, and that she and another female employee worried that the lawmaker wanted to have sex as a means of impregnating them.

headline: In Scorched California, a Year of ‘Epic Firefighting’ Is Testing Limits
text: VENTURA, Calif. — Fresh off a 24-hour shift in fire-filled valleys, Fabian Uresti, a veteran firefighter from California’s Central Valley, shrugged off the question of whether he would make it home for Christmas.

headline: Liberal Activists to Democrats: Protect Young Immigrants or Shut Down Government
text: WASHINGTON — Liberal activists, eager for Democrats to assert what power they have left in Congress, are pressing Democratic leaders to shut down the government this Christmas if Republicans do not agree to shield young undocumented immigrants from deportation.

headline: Jerusalem Denial Complex
text: If nothing else, Donald Trump’s decision on Wednesday to recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s capital shows how disenthralled his administration is with traditional pieties about the Middle East. It’s about time.

headline: Don’t Give Kids Holiday Gifts That Can Spy on Them
text: SAN FRANCISCO — During the holiday season, my husband and I tend to offer suggestions to those who are generous enough to insist on buying presents for our kids. Things like “Don’t spend more than $50” and “No guns.” Or, for those with whom we can be comfortably blunt, “Just cash, please.”

headline: What Facebook Taught Me About Net Neutrality
text: My first glimpse of a world without strong protections for net neutrality was in 2004, when I was part of the team that created Facebook. Though it’s hard to imagine now, TheFacebook (as it was called at the time) was just a fledgling college social network, growing school by school. Some colleges didn’t like Facebook, and because they functioned as their students’ internet providers, they would simply block the site.

headline: Shohei Ohtani Could Be an Angel in the Outfield, and on the Mound
text: What could be a new era in baseball now appears ready for a tryout next year in Anaheim, Calif.

headline: Trump’s Scare Tactics on North Korea Scare Us
text: North Korea’s launch last week of a type of missile that may soon be able to deliver a nuclear warhead to the United States mainland set off the Trump administration on a troubling new trajectory.

headline: Let’s Talk About Closing the Subway
text: Politicians often shun the suggestion that they should avoid clichés like the plague, and officeholders in New York are no exception. Some of them have leaned extra hard lately on one of their more shopworn banalities: how theirs is the city that never sleeps.

headline: The Scoundrel Theory of American Politics
text: THERE have always been and always will be scoundrels in political life, especially one particular genus — the hypocrite — whose private behavior diverges from his public actions. But there is also a novel and ominous concept of the statesman emerging in American politics, most clearly in the gymnastic contortions being accomplished to justify support for the Senate campaign of Roy Moore, the former chief justice of Alabama: the politician as a disembodied policy array.

headline: Mikheil Saakashvili, Ex-President of Georgia, Arrested in Ukraine, Again
text: MOSCOW — Mikheil Saakashvili, the former president of Georgia, was arrested on Friday in Ukraine during a late-night police raid on an apartment where he had been hiding after his escape from custody following a rooftop struggle with security agents this week.

headline: Two Teams Are Out on Giancarlo Stanton; Could the Yankees Be In?
text: With 59 home runs and a National League Most Valuable Player Award last season, Giancarlo Stanton gave a precious gift to Derek Jeter, the new chief executive of the Miami Marlins. Stanton, in full bloom as baseball’s pre-eminent slugger, would be a commodity on the trade market.

headline: The Man Who Shot Vietnam
text: On Dec. 6, 1967, Horst Faas, the chief photographer of The Associated Press in Vietnam, was pinned down in a slim trench among the rubber trees lining the American air base at Bu Dop, just a few miles from the Cambodian border. It was less than two months before the launch of the Tet offensive and the area was teeming with Viet Cong activity.

headline: Doom Season in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — Before the fires came, our skin turned dry and the winds cleared the smog from the air. November passed with barely any rain, and on Thanksgiving the high was 92 degrees. We Angelenos had been blessed with a beautiful autumn. But all the while, we felt a sense of doom.

headline: Terrorist Groups Vow Bloodshed over Jerusalem Decision. ISIS? Less So.
text: Osama bin Laden was just 14 when his mother noticed that he had stopped watching his favorite Westerns. She found him fixated instead on news reports about Palestinians, tears streaming down his face as he watched TV in their home in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Giggle
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — As Deb and her intrepid cruciverbal Argonauts embark, so I arise from the depths of the Atlantic, rubbing the salt from my eyes and brushing the mermaid’s purses out of my hair, for there can be but one of us at a time at sea, and only one ruling the land.

headline: Bears Ears Is Here to Stay
text: This will always be Native land. But the protections President Trump is gutting are sorely needed.

headline: Quotation of the Day: At Columbia, Three Women, 30 Years and a Pattern of Harassment
text: “I played the game I learned in seventh grade when a boy likes you. You make up some reason so that you protect their feelings, so that they don’t get angry with you, and you still manage to escape. It’s a skill a 12-year-old girl learns that she needs for the rest of her life.”

headline: Corrections: December 9, 2017
text: NATIONAL

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Selma’ and the Major League Soccer Cup
text: Ava DuVernay’s “Selma” airs on FXM. And the Seattle Sounders play the Toronto FC in the finale of the Major League Soccer Cup.

headline: Explore Bears Ears Through Indigenous Voices
text: Bears Ears National Monument is at the center of America’s public lands debate. Visit the area in 360 and hear from some of the people affected by the boundary change.

headline: The Oberoi Hotel in New Delhi Got a Major Makeover. Here Is a First Look.
text: New Delhi’s Oberoi hotel has a dear place in my heart, as it does for many city natives. On special occasions, including my sixth birthday, my parents and grandmother would take my sister and me to the property’s restaurant, the Café, for afternoon tea and pastries — the flaky chocolate cake was a favorite. But my family’s affiliation with the property predated me: my mother, Kiran, and my father, Vikesh, used to frequent the Oberoi’s lobby in the early 1970s with their college friends; the hotel was the epicenter for India’s glitterati, and they were always on the lookout for a boldface sighting.

headline: With Alabama Senate Race Defined by Scandal, Policy Issues Are Overlooked
text: HALEYVILLE, Ala. — The hospital here, the only one in the county, is planning to close this month.

headline: 10 Hot Toys That Changed the Way People Play
text: The Fingerling Monkey may be this year’s hottest toy, but its popularity is far from unparalleled. A new must-have toy seems to arrive every holiday season. Richard Gottlieb, the chief executive of Global Toy Experts and publisher of Global Toy News, discussed some of the Fingerling’s craze-making predecessors over the last generation.

headline: How the Fingerling Caught On (Robot Grip and All) as 2017’s Hot Toy
text: About two years ago, Sydney Wiseman had a challenging assignment for an engineer at her family toy company.

headline: ‘You Know, I Never Told You This’
text: After millions of #MeToo tweets and an onslaught of media exposés of sexual misconduct accusations against public figures, some readers are broaching the topic of sexual assault with their families, revealing experiences they once felt too ashamed to discuss.

headline: Welcome to China’s Florida: Sun, Sand and Retired Snowbirds
text: SANYA, China — While the white-sand beaches and five-star international resorts are meant to be the main attraction, for the hundreds of thousands of Chinese retirees who descend upon this tropical city every winter, dancing on the seaside promenade is often the real draw.

headline: Listen to ‘Dear Sugars’: Just Say It
text: Words can be wielded like weapons. On today’s episode we hear from letter writers who have something to confess but are afraid to hurt others with the power of their words.

headline: Hey, ‘Budtender’: Los Angeles’s Power Brokers of Pot Crank Up the Kook
text: LOS ANGELES — Carli Jo Bidlingmaier was talking to a group of 20-somethings in a living room in the Bel-Air neighborhood here, weeks before the wildfires. She was explaining that consuming marijuana allows a woman to awaken her “yoni,” a Sanskrit term for vagina favored by Hollywood bohemians.

headline: Leave the Bucket Lists to Those Ambitious Boomers. It’s Tee Time.
text: Before Art Lerner retired, he could not imagine how he would fill the days. He had few hobbies — come to think of it, only one: fishing. But at his firm’s urging, Mr. Lerner, a money manager, had already stayed on the job for three more years than he intended, and “I’d had enough,” he said.

headline: After-School Special
text: It really started around my fifth year in New York — both friends and strangers telling me that I needed to accept the harsh reality of becoming a “New Yorker.” This conversation was always awkward, less because of the premise and more the tone: It was consistently less congratulatory and more gotcha. But that made sense: New York City is the great collector of souls, eternally capable in the art of lengthening stays and erasing plans of ever leaving.

headline: The Long Search to Ferret Out the ‘Salvator Mundi’ Buyer
text: Perhaps the most challenging — often maddening — aspect of covering auctions is trying to figure out who bought what. Indeed, the competitive current coursing through the press corps at any auction is largely fueled by the desire to match the dealers or art advisers bidding in the room (or the auction specialists taking bids on the phone) with the buyers they represent.

headline: Readers and The Times Respond to Harvey Weinstein’s Page One Portrait
text: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

headline: Boris Johnson Presses Iran on Detained Britons
text: TEHRAN — Britain’s foreign secretary, Boris Johnson, expressed concern on Saturday in Tehran about British-Iranian citizens detained in Iran, a group that includes Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, whose trial and imprisonment has stirred tensions between the two nations.

headline: 3 Homages to Nature
text: As President Trump prepares to shrink two national monuments in Utah, here are three books by writers who have presented passionate cases for the preservation of nature.

headline: Janet Yellen Didn’t Set Out to Be a Feminist Hero
text: She has been called “a small lady with a large I.Q.” She has been mocked for wearing the same outfit to both her official White House nomination and her confirmation hearing. (“At least we know her mind won’t be preoccupied with haute couture,” a Washington gossip columnist wrote.) And when President Barack Obama once referred to Janet L. Yellen as “Mr. Yellen,” she didn’t bother correcting him.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
text: Welcome to the weekend. Keep your PJ’s on a little longer. Put on some holiday music, sink into a comfortable chair and give yourself the gift of reading because we have some great stories for you!

headline: For Older Venezuelans, Fleeing Crisis Means ‘Starting From Zero,’ Even at 90
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — María Abad Cruz, 90, sits on the cusp of her fourth migration, and it may be the hardest one.

headline: ‘Merci, Johnny’: Hallyday Honored With Rock-Star Funeral (and Motorbikes)
text: PARIS — Hundreds of motorcycles roared down the Champs-Élysées and crowds sang in unison as tens of thousands of fans of Johnny Hallyday, the French rock star who died this past week, lined the streets of Paris on Saturday for his funeral procession.

headline: Can Marriott Keep Starwood’s Culture of Cool, and Its Customers?
text: PITTSBURGH — Consider the conundrum of the modern hotel-room shopper.

headline: A North Korean Defector Is Spurned, for Decades, by South Korea
text: ANSAN, South Korea — Few North Koreans have sought South Korean citizenship as long and as doggedly as Kim Seok-cheol.

headline: The Rich and Royal History of Purple, the Color of 2018
text: We interrupt your daily newsfeed with this message brought to you by purple, which traveled all the way from ancient times to become the color of 2018.

headline: It’s Sluggers Inc., as Giancarlo Stanton Joins Aaron Judge on the Yankees
text: For two years, the Yankees moved deftly through an uncharacteristic rebuilding process, establishing a growing nucleus of inexpensive and talented young players that seemed to defy the team’s long-established identity as one of the biggest spenders in baseball.

headline: A Food Writer Gives His Bride ‘Four Stars’
text: Paola Briseño González and Javier Cabral were married Dec. 9 at Villa Mandarinas in the resort town of Puerto Vallarta, in Jalisco, Mexico. Judge Noemi Palacios officiated. Earlier in the day, Rojelio Cabral, a brother of the groom, led a spiritual ceremony at the same place.

headline: Can the Landlord Do Anything to Help Prevent Package Theft?
text: Q. Packages, including mine, have been taken from the mailroom of my rental apartment building in Hudson Heights. I filed a police report and alerted building management. Someone was arrested. But I am still concerned about security in our non-doorman building. For example, I saw a deliveryman using a credit card to pop open the lock to the entrance door to make a delivery. I have spoken with neighbors about circulating a petition demanding that the landlord improve security. But what are our rights? With the holidays coming, deliveries will only increase.

headline: A Dentist’s Office Disguised as an Undersea Playground
text: We spoke with Joeamy Rios, a dental assistant at Adelberg Montalvan Pediatric Dental and Orthopedics in Nesconset, N.Y., about working in an office with an aquatic theme.

headline: Ojai, Calif., Ringed by Flames, Is an Ash-Covered Shangri-La
text: OJAI, Calif. — Ernest Niglio traded Brooklyn 20 years ago for healthy, spiritual living in this laid-back, picturesque town.

headline: Pessimism and Paralysis in the Aftermath of the Financial Crisis
text: The latest job report was very good, except for one thing: wage growth is still much lower than it was before the financial crisis. And this reminds me of a controversy that raged around four or five years ago, during what now seems like a golden age – an era when it seemed as if facts and reasoned debate might actually matter for policy.

headline: He Wanted to Stay Sober. So He Surrounded Himself With Drinkers.
text: Each night, after closing time at the Manhattan restaurant where Michael McGarry works, his colleagues wind down with whiskey sours and pale ales. Mr. McGarry takes a different drink, usually an espresso or a sparkling water.

headline: Where to Watch Centuries of British History Through the Screen
text: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.

headline: Reza Zarrab Reveals a Plot to Kill Him, and Is Accused of Rape
text: Reza Zarrab, the star prosecution witness in the trial of a Turkish banker charged in a billion-dollar scheme to violate United States sanctions on Iran, was in his seventh day of testimony in Manhattan this past week when he revealed what he called a jailhouse attempt to kill him.

headline: Inside Trump’s Hour-by-Hour Battle for Self-Preservation
text: WASHINGTON — Around 5:30 each morning, President Trump wakes and tunes into the television in the White House’s master bedroom. He flips to CNN for news, moves to “Fox & Friends” for comfort and messaging ideas, and sometimes watches MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” because, friends suspect, it fires him up for the day.

headline: Iraq Prime Minister Declares Victory Over ISIS
text: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq declared victory over the Islamic State on Saturday, announcing the end of more than three years of battles to regain control over nearly one-third of the country that had been under the terrorist group’s dominion.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I have a big soft spot in my heart for Ann Patchett, the author quoted in today’s Cox and Rathvon acrostic. At one point in my life, I (along with a lot of other people, I’m sure) recommended the “Patron Saint of Liars” to anyone and everyone I met.

headline: How to Save Money on Your Prescription Drugs
text: If you’re willing to do a little extra work, it is possible to lower your prescription bills.

headline: Prescription Drugs May Cost More With Insurance Than Without It
text: This article was written through collaboration between The New York Times and ProPublica, the independent, nonprofit investigative journalism organization.

headline: Tax Plans May Give Your Co-Worker a Better Deal Than You
text: In most places, a dollar is a dollar. But in the tax code envisioned by Republicans, the amount you make may be less important than how you make it.

headline: U.S. Put 92 Somalis on a Deportation Flight, Then Brought Them Back
text: Ninety-two Somali citizens were flown out of the United States under orders of deportation on Thursday, but their plane never made it to Somalia. The flight landed in the West African country of Senegal and, facing logistical problems, was rerouted back to the United States.

headline: Team to Lead City Ballet During Martins Sexual Harassment Probe
text: New York City Ballet has selected an interim leadership team pending an internal investigation into sexual harassment allegations against Peter Martins, its ballet master in chief, the company announced on Saturday.

headline: Tommy John Would Love a Plaque to Accompany All of His Fame
text: If the call comes for Tommy John late on Sunday afternoon, he will be ready. He lives in Palm Springs, Calif., and can make it to Los Angeles International Airport in plenty of time for a midnight flight to baseball’s winter meetings in Orlando, Fla. If he takes the flight, it will mean that he has finally made the Hall of Fame.

headline: Street Outside Russian Embassy in Washington May Be Renamed for a Dissident
text: WASHINGTON — At a Washington city council meeting this past week, Zhanna Nemtsova held aloft a blue sign with Russian script in white. The words, she said, translated as “Nemtsov Bridge.” The sign itself was a copy of ones left on a stretch of sidewalk in Moscow where her father, the Russian democratic activist Boris Y. Nemtsov, was gunned down in 2015.

headline: Moore’s Rebuke of His Accuser and Other Distortions in Alabama’s Senate Race
text: WASHINGTON — At a Friday night rally, President Trump urged supporters to vote for Roy S. Moore, the Republican candidate in an Alabama Senate race who has been accused of sexual misconduct.

headline: Jerusalem: It’s Tense, Crowded and Can Feel Like a Jail
text: JERUSALEM — This is a tense city on a good day.

headline: The Jerusalem Issue, Explained
text: Why is President Trump’s announcement that the United States now considers Jerusalem to be Israel’s capital such a big deal? Why are some experts warning of violence or an end to the peace process? What’s the dispute over Jerusalem all about, anyway? Let’s review.

headline: Roadkill on Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON — Alan Simpson was appalled by the injustice of it all.

headline: Palestinians’ Dashed Hopes for Jerusalem
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — My nephew Aziz, a bright young man who returned to Ramallah this summer after studying in London, called me on Thursday morning, the day after the decision by the United States to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.

headline: The Baker and the Empire
text: There are fine constitutional lawyers who can argue back and forth about the Masterpiece Cakeshop case the Supreme Court heard last week, which will determine whether a Christian baker can decline to make a same-sex couple’s wedding cake. The court’s decision will either limit antidiscrimination law or limit First Amendment protections, so it’s not surprising that you can find deeply-footnoted legal arguments on both sides.

headline: For Veterans, a Path to Healing ‘Moral Injury’
text: When you have a physical injury, go to the doctor. A psychological injury? Get thee to a psychiatrist. But what can be done if you suffer from a “moral injury?”

headline: How Arctic Drilling, Stymied for Decades, Made Surprise Return in Tax Bill
text: WASHINGTON — As another fevered push to open the pristine Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to energy exploration collapsed on the Senate floor in December 2005, Ted Stevens, then the powerful and wily Republican senator from Alaska, declared it “the saddest day of my life.”

headline: Macron Steps Into Middle East Role as U.S. Retreats
text: PARIS — A year ago, no one would have envisioned President Emmanuel Macron of France as the public face of Western diplomacy in the Middle East. But that is not the case anymore.

headline: I Grew Up Around Korean Beauty Products. Americans, You’ve Been Had.
text: I admit it: I use Korean snail slime face serum. It’s purported to contain anti-aging properties. I have no opinion as to whether snails are particularly young-looking, but my experience is that their excretions do work on humans. That aside, as someone who grew up among Korean beauty products, I find the world’s sudden fascination with Korean skin care, and its now-famous 12-step regimen, to be comical.

headline: An Abomination. A Monster. That’s Me?
text: It used to be that when someone called me an abomination, I was in the presence of a homophobe.

headline: Why I Can No Longer Call Myself an Evangelical Republican
text: There are times in life when the institutional ground underneath you begins to crumble — and with it, longstanding attachments. Such is the case for me when it comes to the Republican Party and evangelicalism.

headline: The Looting of America’s Public Lands
text: The protections put in place over the last half-century by both political parties to guarantee Americans clean air, clean water and bountiful open space have been coming apart at the seams since President Trump took office. The last few weeks have been particularly brutal for conservationists and, indeed, anyone who believes that big chunks of America’s public lands, however rich they may be in commercial resources, are best left in their natural state.

headline: The Importance of Dumb Mistakes in College
text: It seemed like a good idea at the time.

headline: Pruitt Moves to Curb E.P.A.’s Power to Demand Pollution Tests
text: E.P.A. enforcement officials nationwide rely on provisions of the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts that enable them to order polluters to test their emissions for legal violations. Mr. Pruitt, after a request from the oil industry, has put new limits on that power.

headline: Alabama, Despite History of Unruly Politics, Has ‘Never Seen Anything Like This’
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — “I don’t think you can compare this one with anything,” said Bill Baxley, 76, whose first foray into Alabama state politics was as attorney general nearly five decades ago.

headline: Trump, Rejecting Calls to Stay Away, Speaks at Civil Rights Museum
text: JACKSON, Miss. — President Trump’s presence jolted the opening of a civil rights museum here on Saturday, generating boycotts from some leaders in the movement and small protests by activists as the state’s attempt to confront its racially violent past clashed with more recent divisions wrought by Mr. Trump’s presidency.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Office Secret Santa Guidelines for 2017
text: Dear Colleagues,

headline: Roy Moore’s Alabama
text: ARLEY, Ala. — I recently drove the back roads from Birmingham for over two hours before I finally found a sign for Roy Moore, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, outside the Arley Coffee Shop. A retired coal miner who frequents what the cashier called the “liars’ table” put it to me in the familiar Winston County way. “The women,” he said of Mr. Moore’s accusers, were lying to make him look like a sexual predator. “Groping,” he added, “used to be all right anyway.”

headline: From 2017: Video Shows Daniel Shaver Pleading for His Life Before Being Shot by Officer
text: [For more about police violence and unrest, go here]

headline: In Indonesia, Women Begin to Fight ‘Epidemic’ of Street Harassment
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Tunggal Pawestri says she’ll never forget being groped on a public bus while traveling to her high school in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, when she was 14.

headline: Full-Body Cast
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Some people love the holidays, others get melancholy, some people do both. The end of the year leads to nostalgia, lists, a statistical increase in lists of statistics. For those of us wedged into the Northern Hemisphere, the days are ridiculously short, and unless your time is consumed by delivering toys or a gingerbread business, it’s pretty sweet to hunker down for the night, at 4:30 p.m., with a weekend puzzle to dissect that gives your brain a bit of a workout.

headline: DNA Tattoos Are the Final Frontier of Love
text: It all began with a floating leg.

headline: With 2020 Census Looming, Worries About Fairness and Accuracy
text: WASHINGTON — Census experts and public officials are expressing growing concerns that the bedrock mission of the 2020 census — an accurate and trustworthy head count of everyone in the United States — is imperiled, with worrisome implications.

headline: Parents, How Did You Get That Hot Toy? Share Your Story.
text: The New York Times wants to know to what lengths you have gone to get your child a toy for the holidays.

headline: Toronto F.C. Wins M.L.S. Cup, and a Little Redemption
text: TORONTO — Toronto F.C. barreled into this season’s M.L.S. Cup final as something of a juggernaut. With the most expensive roster in the league, Toronto amassed a league-record 69 points in the regular season and, a year after losing the championship game on its home field, stormed back to the final.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Making of the No. 1 Monkey
text: “You know you can trust a toy company if its toys fart. It knows what kids want.”

headline: The Yankees Will Always Be the Yankees, to the Delight of Only Some
text: There are more teams in Major League Baseball than players who have hit 50 home runs in a season. Thirty teams, 29 sluggers. Only one team has had two players hit 50 in the same year: the 1961 Yankees, one of the most overpowering teams in the history of the sport.

text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Angels Unveil Shohei Ohtani, Who Exudes Promise and Prudence
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Coming from Japan, Shohei Ohtani did not know how long it would take to choose his new team, or whether that team would be in the American or National League, or where that team played, but he wanted to prepare himself for every possibility. As proof, he said, examine his wardrobe on Saturday, when he was unveiled by the Los Angeles Angels.

headline: Jeanne LaFrance, Michael Ervolini
text: Jeanne Catherine LaFrance and Michael Albert Ervolini are to be married Dec. 10 at the Lenox Hotel in Boston. Richard W. Lewis, a friend of the couple, received authorization from the secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage.

text: Laura Sulin Carling and Michael Ross Hartman were married Dec. 9. The Rev. Dr. Paul J. Carling, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bride, officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

text: Mary Elizabeth Baskerville and Theodore Ross Newman were married Dec. 9 at the Church of St. Monica in New York. The Rev. James R. Gould, who is a Roman Catholic priest and the bride’s godfather, led the ceremony with Rabbi David Schaefer participating.

text: Anna Malaika Grace Ntiriwah Asare and Michael Derrick Tubbs were married Dec. 5. The Rev. Glenn R. Shields, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Progressive Community Church in Stockton, Calif., where he is the senior pastor. On Dec. 9, the couple had another ceremony with friends and family at the Iglesia de San Pedro Claver in Cartagena, Colombia.

headline: Katherine Pantone, Kevin Rose
