At the agency’s request, Spanish security officers in April arrested the man, Pyotr Y. Levashov, who is accused of stuffing untold millions of inboxes with ads for pornography, pills and penny stocks.

headline: School Sex-Abuse Report Shows Difficulty of Substantiating Claims
text: KIPP Academy, an influential national charter network, released a report on Wednesday detailing accusations of sexual misconduct by two teachers at one of its New York City schools years ago.

headline: Sloppy Joes!
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: Susan Rice: When America No Longer Is a Global Force for Good
text: President Trump’s National Security Strategy marks a dramatic departure from the plans of his Republican and Democratic predecessors, painting a dark, almost dystopian portrait of an “extraordinarily dangerous” world characterized by hostile states and lurking threats. There is scant mention of America’s unrivaled political, military, technological and economic strength, or the opportunities to expand prosperity, freedom and security through principled leadership — the foundation of American foreign policy since World War II.

headline: Using Technology to Be Environmentally Friendly
text: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Hiroko Tabuchi, a climate and environment reporter for The Times, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline: The Year in Gender 2017
text: From women’s marches around the world to an avalanche of sexual misconduct scandals, here are the biggest stories involving women’s and gender issues from 2017. Sign up for the new #MeToo Moment newsletter, and read more about our new gender initiative here.

headline: 2 Women Who Settled With O’Reilly Over Sexual Harassment Sue for Defamation
text: Two women who reached sexual harassment settlements with Bill O’Reilly joined a defamation lawsuit against Mr. O’Reilly and Fox News on Wednesday, asserting that statements that he and the network made depicted them as liars, political operatives and extortionists.

headline: National Signing Day: Georgia Adds Cade Mays to Strong Class
text: Wednesday is the first day of a new event in the crowded college football calendar: an earlier national signing period.

headline: Give Thanks for the Winter Solstice. You Might Not Be Here Without It.
text: [This article, which was originally published for 2017’s winter solstice, has been updated for 2019. Sign up for The Times Space Calendar here.]

headline: In an Unsettled Life, Singing Opera Became Her Rock
text: Solita Hanna unexpectedly rose from her seat when social workers asked women at a Brooklyn shelter to share their talents during a party.

headline: Inside Bunny Mellon’s $8.9 Million Central Park Condo
text: A tour of the 28th floor Central Park apartment of Rachel Lambert “Bunny” Mellon, the socialite heiress who died in 2014 at the age of 103.

headline: Bunny Mellon’s Central Park Aerie Lists for $8.9 Million
text: The estate of Rachel Lambert Mellon, the millionaire heiress and tastemaker known as Bunny, has been selling off her massive collection of art, fashion and fineries since her death in 2014, at the age of 103. But there are gems yet to be sold.

headline: An American Jewish Author Now Calls Germany Home
text: BERLIN — Deborah Feldman has learned to follow the sun. December marks the 31-year-old Brooklyn-raised writer’s fourth winter living in Berlin, a place notorious for its long, gray months, and by now she has it down: On the rare days when the cloud cover breaks, she hurries to her local market hall, a 100-year-old, light-flooded space in Berlin’s Kreuzberg neighborhood. There, the sun shines around noon, for an hour.

headline: Writing Prompts, Quizzes, Lessons and Graphs: Our Most Popular Teaching and Learning Resources in 2017
text: We’d like to add to the chorus of New York Times year-end lists — from Best Books and Most Important Scientific Findings to Five Times the Internet Was Actually Fun — by sorting a few of our own resources for you, with the hope that they help when you’re back in the classroom in January.

headline: Ukraine War Flares Again After a Lull
text: MOSCOW — The war in rebel-held eastern Ukraine has escalated sharply this week, with the heaviest fighting in nearly a year, European observers and Western diplomats reported on Wednesday.

headline: With Tax Overhaul, Trump Fulfills a Campaign Promise and Flexes Republican Muscle
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump ended a chaotic first year by achieving his most convincing legislative triumph on Wednesday, making good on his promise to deliver what he called a “big, beautiful” tax cut before Christmas and finally demonstrating the political power of unified Republican control in Washington.

headline: Making Plans for an Insecure Planet
text: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: In 2017, Many Athletes Found Their Voices
text: It was the year when athletes got political again, very political.

headline: Trump, Leakers, Travel Ban: Our Most Commented-On Articles of 2017
text: We on The New York Times’s Community desk have never been busier. This year we shattered the previous record for the most commented-on news article in Times history (see that story revealed below). Under the hood, The Times adopted a new moderation platform that allowed us to open more stories for comments than ever before.

headline: The Year in Sports
text: Incredible comebacks, unbelievable shots and memorable performances in 2017.

headline: ‘Password,’ ‘Monkey’ and the Other Terrible Passwords We Choose
text: The list of this year’s 25 “worst” passwords says a lot about us.

headline: Santa in Finland, Where Marketing Triumphs Over Geography
text: ROVANIEMI, Finland — Here in Santa Claus Village, near the Arctic Circle, is the self-anointed “official Santa,” a Finn who refused to give his real name, insisting he was actually Mr. Claus.

headline: Trump Threatens to End American Aid: ‘We’re Watching Those Votes’ at the U.N.
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump issued a threat on Wednesday to cut off American aid to any country that votes for a resolution at the United Nations condemning his recent decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.

headline: The Trojan Horse in the Tax Bill
text: Congressional Republicans have finally done it: Both the House and Senate passed tax legislation. The bill has now headed to President Trump’s desk for his signature.

headline: ‘Cat Person’ Author, Kristen Roupenian, Gets 7-Figure Book Deal
text: The author of the short story “Cat Person,” which became a viral phenomenon after appearing in The New Yorker this month, has received a seven-figure book deal, according to a person with knowledge of the deal.

headline: 2017: The Year in National
text: For students at Flint Northwestern High School, this year’s prom was a chance to set aside anxieties about Flint’s three-year-old water crisis, its poverty and its gun violence.

headline: Corey Johnson Gains Support in Council Speaker Race
text: The race to become the next City Council speaker entered its final stages on Wednesday with leaders from the two most powerful Democratic county organizations, in the Bronx and in Queens, solidifying support behind a Manhattan councilman, Corey Johnson, according to four people with direct knowledge of the discussions, who spoke anonymously because they did not have permission to disclose the choice.

headline: Another Florida Star Departs as the Rays Trade Evan Longoria
text: Major League Baseball has a natural foothold in Florida, its warm climate attracting teams for spring training since the 1880s. In some ways, the state still seems more comfortable with visitors than permanent residents.

headline: U.S. Punishes Chechen Leader in New Sanctions Against Russians
text: WASHINGTON — The United States imposed sanctions on five Russian individuals on Wednesday, including the leader of the Republic of Chechnya, for alleged human rights abuses and involvement in criminal conspiracies, a sign that the Trump administration is ratcheting up pressure on Russia.

headline: Giving a Family Business a Jolt With Coffee That Empowers Women
text: MINNEAPOLIS — As a child, Alyza Bohbot always respected the unflappable work ethic of her parents, who ran Alakef Coffee Roasters in Duluth, Minn. Still, in late 2014, when she was in her 20s, that didn’t stop her from warning them of their company’s potential downfall.

headline: Republican Party, European Union, Solstice: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Your Week in Culture: Shaina Taub, Lady Gaga, ‘Genius Grant’ Tap Dance
text: New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts — it’s a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Dec. 17, seven events in New York, Los Angeles and elsewhere not to be missed:

headline: In Praise of William James
text: I’ve devoted a significant chunk of this one life I have to reading, though I really don’t believe that books offer any greater chance of salvation than, say, windsurfing. Yet I can’t help feeling that I was saved, for a while, by William James.

headline: Video Game Creators Seek Out Hollywood for Robust Narratives
text: When Pete Samuels, a founder and the chief executive of Supermassive Games, began working on a survival horror adventure video game called Until Dawn in 2015, he knew he wanted the story to unfold like that of a horror film.

headline: The Year in Boxed Sets, From Weird Al to Frank Zappa
text: What’s past is product. Career retrospectives, live recordings, archival digs and technological upgrades share the landscape of boxed sets released this year, bringing new perspective to both superstars and cult figures. Here, the music critics of The New York Times choose some of the most notable collections of 2017.

headline: That Danger of Driving While Different
text: To the Editor:

headline: McKayla Maroney Says USA Gymnastics Forced Confidentiality in Sexual Abuse Settlement
text: Facing a proliferation of sexual assault allegations involving a former team doctor, USA Gymnastics, the governing body for the sport, last year signed a nondisclosure agreement as part of a settlement with one of the accusers, McKayla Maroney.

headline: Review: Dorrance Dance, Tapping Out the Joy
text: Michelle Dorrance’s newly expanded work “Myelination” takes its title from science. It refers to the formation of myelin sheaths around neurons, a process that speeds up the transmission of nerve impulses — and an apt analogy for a dance brimming with electricity, with movement so swift it defies comprehension. For Ms. Dorrance, the impulses are rhythmic — her medium is tap — and they travel among the dancers with the efficiency and inevitability of a biological phenomenon.

headline: The Rushed Passage of a Tax Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, Top Human Rights Official, Won’t Seek a Second Term
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations High Commissioner for human rights, who has openly criticized powerful governments, including the Trump administration, has made the unusual decision to not seek a second four-year term, saying it “might involve bending a knee in supplication.”

headline: Researchers Warn of a Spreading Fungus Deadly to Snakes
text: One of the first hints that yet another fungal disease that could devastate wildlife was emerging in the United States came in 2006 with a report that an isolated winter den of timber rattlesnakes in New Hampshire had suffered a population crash.

headline: Attending the Nobel Prize Ceremony After Trump Snubbed the Winners
text: Last week, we found ourselves in an unexpected place: in the very back of the top balcony in the Stockholm Concert Hall, watching as King Carl XVI Gustaf awarded medals to this year’s Nobel  laureates — in physics, chemistry, physiology or medicine, literature and economics. As Americans spending the year in Sweden, we were honored and surprised to learn that we had been invited. While we were inspired by the pageantry of the celebration of human achievement, we were simultaneously sobered by the realization that the Trump administration is attacking the very institutions that make Nobel Prize-winning careers possible. In doing so, our country is charting a path to its own irrelevance.

headline: How to Know if Republicans’ Big Tax Bet Is Paying Off
text: The tax bill passed by Congress on Wednesday is effectively a giant bet that benefits given to companies and the wealthy will help average workers. That makes them a big risk for the Republicans who control Congress. Here are five factors to measure the policy’s success.

headline: Resort Wear for Anywhere
text: It’s resort season in fashion. Which means that whether or not you find yourself in a resort anytime soon, the stores have plenty of covetable styles to transport you to a beachy state of mind. And for those of you lucky enough to be decamping for warmer climes, comes the eternal question: What to pack? Happily, these three new companies have some tips, tricks (palo sticks and dust bags are involved) and lots of pretty things that will help answer the query.

headline: A Scene From ‘Molly’s Game’
text: Jessica Chastain and Idris Elba in a sequence from the film “Molly’s Game,” adapted for the screen and directed by Aaron Sorkin.

headline: Street Etiquette’s Joshua Kissi Diversifies Stock Photos
text: Joshua Kissi

headline: Can Anita Hill Fix Hollywood’s Harassment Problem?
text: As a powerhouse producer for Steven Spielberg and now president of Lucasfilm, Kathleen Kennedy has for decades tackled some of Hollywood’s most famous monsters: gremlins, poltergeists, T. rexes and the dark side of the Force.

headline: Cardinal Law and the U.S.-Rome Sex Abuse Divide
text: ROME — Early on Wednesday morning, hours after Cardinal Bernard F. Law died in a Rome hospital, a priest unlocked a small chapel at the Basilica of St. Mary Major and pointed to the spot under the marble altar and life-size crucifix where the once-mighty American prelate had arranged to be buried.

headline: The Nuclear Showdown in Georgia
text: Georgia is on the cusp of a very important decision about nuclear energy. We shouldn’t miss what’s at stake.

headline: You Ain’t Seen Nothing Yet!
text: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.

headline: Rome’s ‘Mangy’ Christmas Tree Is a Sorry Sight: ‘It Has Clearly Been Traumatized’
text: ROME — No sooner had workers hoisted a 72-foot tall Norway spruce in Rome’s central Piazza Venezia this month than the mocking began.

headline: Mistrial Declared in Bundy Armed Standoff Case
text: A federal judge declared a mistrial on Wednesday in the case of Nevada cattle ranchers and one of their supporters, whose dispute with the government over grazing rights turned into an armed standoff in 2014. The judge stated that prosecutors had improperly withheld evidence from the defense.

headline: Uganda Lifts an Age Limit, Paving the Way for a President for Life
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — After months of heated, sometimes violent debate, Uganda’s Parliament voted late Wednesday to lift the age limit for the presidency, setting the stage for President Yoweri Museveni to rule the country indefinitely.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Kristin Scott Thomas Reads ‘How the Dining Dead Got Talking Again’
text: On this week’s podcast, the actress Kristin Scott Thomas tells the story of a couple that falls out of — and back into — conversation. The essay, “How the Dining Dead Got Talking Again,” was written by Molly Pascal and published in Modern Love last year.

headline: Trump and G.O.P. Celebrate Tax Bill
text: The passage of the tax overhaul bill is the biggest legislative achievement for Republicans since they gained full control of Congress and the White House.

headline: After Court Victory, Detained Teenage Immigrants Are Allowed to Obtain Abortions
text: Two teenage unauthorized immigrants who sued the Trump administration to be allowed to obtain abortions while in custody are free to end their pregnancies, even as the legal fight continues over the policy that had prevented them from doing so.

headline: Glenn Thrush, Suspended Times Reporter, to Resume Work but Won’t Cover White House
text: The New York Times said on Wednesday that Glenn Thrush, one of the paper’s most prominent political reporters, would remain suspended until late January and then be removed from the team covering the White House after he faced allegations of inappropriate sexual behavior.

headline: A One-Vote Victory in Virginia Lasts One Day as Judges Declare a Tie
text: A day after a dramatic recount handed Democrats a single-vote victory in a Virginia House of Delegates race, the outcome abruptly shifted on Wednesday as a three-judge panel declared the race now tied.

headline: Review: ‘Pitch Perfect 3’ Keeps the Songs but Loses the Plot
text: When fans of the wry “Pitch Perfect” series first met the ragtag singing group the Barden Bellas, they were ensconced in the college a cappella bubble. “Pitch Perfect 3” finally bursts that bubble, following the Bellas into adult life. We are reintroduced to the group’s reluctant leader, Beca (Anna Kendrick), as she quits a demeaning record label job. In the same vein, Chloe (Brittany Snow) endures veterinary school, while Fat Amy (Rebel Wilson) coasts on her Fat Amy Winehouse impersonation. Discouraged by the demands of the real world, the larger-than-life Bellas reunite to join a U.S.O. tour, where they vie to perform as the opening act for the record producer DJ Khaled (appearing as himself).

headline: Chuck Close Apologizes After Accusations of Sexual Harassment
text: Chuck Close, the acclaimed artist whose massive portraits reside in the world’s top museums, is facing allegations from several women that he sexually harassed them when they came to his studio to pose for him.

headline: Yu Guangzhong, Exiled Poet Who Longed for China, Dies at 89
text: Yu Guangzhong, a prominent poet, essayist and translator whose best-known work, “Nostalgia,” came to symbolize the aching separation, displacement and longing for cultural unity felt by many in mainland China and in the Chinese diaspora, died on Dec. 14 in Kaohsiung, Taiwan. He was 89.

headline: Aaron Sorkin Annotates Aaron Sorkin
text: Aaron Sorkin annotates the script he wrote for his directorial debut, “Molly’s Game,” starring Jessica Chastain and Idris Elba.

headline: Two Founders Quit Grace, an Acclaimed Chicago Restaurant
text: The chef and the general manager who five years ago opened Grace, a Chicago restaurant considered one of America’s best places to dine, have quit after a dispute with the wealthy Chicago real estate investor who owns it.

headline: A Salad a Day May Be Good for Brain Health
text: Eating leafy greens may help slow mental decline.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
text: Through Dec. 23. McKenzie Fine Art, 55 Orchard Street, Manhattan; 212-989-5467, mckenziefineart.com.

headline: 13 Beloved TV Holiday Specials You Can Stream Right Now
text: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.

headline: Review: A Runaway Slave Rides West in ‘Cross That River’
text: “This sure ain’t a tale you gonna read about in them dime-store Westerns,” the actor and composer Allan Harris confides in “Cross That River” — and he’s right. Look elsewhere for Roy Rogers or the Man With No Name; the hero of this show is Blue, a runaway-slave-turned-cowboy making his way during America’s westward expansion.

headline: A Catholic Priest in Wisconsin Reveals a Secret: ‘I Am Gay’
text: For as long as he could remember, Father Gregory Greiten, a Roman Catholic priest in Wisconsin, lived with an oppressive secret.

headline: Democrats Are Dominating the Generic Ballot. What Does That Mean?
text: Despite all the unusual political events of the last few years, one thing in electoral politics is proceeding by the book: the growing Democratic advantage on the generic congressional ballot.

headline: Theater Professionals Can Seek Mediation in Sexual Harassment Cases
text: Members of the theater community now have a new option for how to address sexual harassment.

headline: Is That Champagne in Your Sorbet? Prove It
text: In a fight that pitted Champagne producers against a discount supermarket, the European Union Court of Justice ruled on Wednesday that the retailer can sell its Champagner Sorbet — but only if it can prove that Champagne is a distinct part of its flavor.

headline: The #MeToo Moment: Blue-Collar Women Ask, ‘What About Us?’
text: As the sexual misconduct scandals continue to unfold, our gender team is providing updates and analysis on the coverage and conversation in a new newsletter. Today, Susan Chira and Catrin Einhorn take us behind the scenes of their reporting into a 25-year pattern of sexual harassment at Ford. Plus, readers share their own stories.

headline: Unless Congress Acts, Nearly 2 Million Children Could Lose Health Coverage in January
text: A new analysis finds that if Congress does not renew federal funding for CHIP, another million could lose coverage in February.

headline: Drilling in Arctic Refuge Gets a Green Light. What’s Next?
text: President Trump on Wednesday was poised to sign the new tax bill, passed by Congress, which lifts a decades-old ban on oil and gas drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northeastern Alaska. Here’s a look at what might happen now.

headline: Republican Economic Policies Put Business First
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican tax bill headed for President Trump’s desk is the most ambitious test yet of his approach to economic policy — that his ideas for strengthening American business will increase the prosperity of the American people.

headline: And the Nominees for President of U.S. Soccer Are ...
text: Two months after a humiliating loss to Trinidad and Tobago ensured the United States men would miss next year’s World Cup, the campaigning to decide who will lead American soccer can officially begin in earnest.

headline: Facebook Job Ads Raise Concerns About Age Discrimination
text: This article was written through collaboration between The New York Times and ProPublica, the independent, nonprofit investigative journalism organization.

headline: Trump Falsely Claims to Have ‘Repealed Obamacare’
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump celebrated the tax bill that Congress approved on Wednesday by characterizing it as a two-for-one victory, falsely claiming that it also made good on his promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Why I Quit Driving
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Pence’s Christmas Pilgrimage Is Canceled. His Next Mideast Move Is Complicated.
text: CAIRO — Vice President Mike Pence’s planned visit to the Middle East, the cradle of Christianity, ought to have had a particular poignancy in the days before Christmas.

headline: Catt Sadler Leaves E! Entertainment, Saying a Male Co-Host Earned Twice as Much
text: Catt Sadler said it was her dream job. After 12 years at E! Entertainment, she was a co-host of two shows, “Daily Pop” during the day and the network’s flagship “E! News” at night.

headline: Republican Party, Jerusalem, Uber: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Trudeau Holiday on Aga Khan’s Island Broke Ethics Law, Report Says
text: OTTAWA — Last Christmas, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and his family were basking in the Caribbean sun on a private island owned by the Aga Khan, the billionaire philanthropist and spiritual leader of Ismaili Muslims.

headline: Iran Sanctions Jury Deliberates: Was Banker a Liar or a Pawn?
text: The jury considering the fate of Mehmet Hakan Atilla, a Turkish banker charged with participating in an oil-for-gold smuggling scheme that violated United States sanctions against Iran, was sent home by the judge on Wednesday after deliberating for half a day without reaching a verdict.

headline: Football Player Says Teammates Sexually Assaulted Him at School Official’s Home
text: The superintendent of a school district in Oklahoma resigned on Tuesday amid allegations that a 16-year-old football player was sexually assaulted with a pool stick by his teammates during an event at the superintendent’s home, officials said.

headline: Carmen Fariña, Head of New York City Schools, Is Retiring
text: Carmen Fariña will retire from her position as New York City’s schools chancellor in the coming months, according to city officials familiar with the discussions. Her retirement is expected to be announced on Thursday.

headline: How a Tuition-Free College Turned Into a Casualty of the Tax Wars
text: Berea College would seem to be an odd target for Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a liberal hero and champion of the little guy. Celebrated as a model for how postsecondary institutions can help fulfill the American dream, the Kentucky liberal arts college admits only students whose families cannot pay for college — 98 percent use federal Pell grants, and 64 percent are first-generation college students.

headline: Officials Weigh Sending American Detainee to Saudi Arabia
text: WASHINGTON — Senior national security officials in the Trump administration are embracing a proposal to transfer to Saudi Arabia an American citizen being held in Iraq as a wartime detainee, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: Why Holiday Stories Matter
text: Just in time for the holidays, our primary season for collective fictions — Ebenezer Scrooge, the Nutcracker Prince, Santa Claus — a team of researchers has published, in the peer-edited journal Nature Communications, the results of an extensive study of storytelling among the Agta, a contemporary population of hunter-gatherers in the Philippines. The lesson: Stories matter.

headline: The Real Coup Plot Is Trump’s
text: When Donald Trump’s campaign was accused of spreading “fake news,” he quickly appropriated the term for himself. The true purveyors of fake news, he claimed, were television networks like CNN and newspapers like this one.

headline: Bill de Blasio Wants to Be Heard. Is Anyone Listening?
text: DES MOINES — The House of Representatives had just passed its sweeping overhaul of the federal tax code, and Mayor Bill de Blasio unfurled his long arms in a windowless Iowa conference room to express his displeasure at what he said was a “bad day for the country.”

headline: Congress Refuses to Do Right by Children’s Health Care
text: As Republican lawmakers celebrate the passage of a tax bill that will make the wealthiest Americans richer, many lower-income families are faced with the real possibility that their children will soon lose their health insurance because Congress didn’t care enough to renew funding for it.

headline: Islanders Say New Arena Will Be Privately Financed
text: The Islanders celebrated a return to Long Island at a news conference on Wednesday at the site of their future home: Belmont Park.

headline: Clifford Irving, Author of a Notorious Literary Hoax, Dies at 87
text: Clifford Irving, who perpetrated one of the biggest literary hoaxes of the 20th century in the early 1970s when he concocted a supposedly authorized autobiography of the billionaire Howard Hughes based on meetings and interviews that never took place, died on Tuesday at a hospice facility near his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87.

headline: When #MeToo Goes Too Far
text: Matt Damon gave an interview to ABC News last week in which he offered the following observation: “There’s a difference between, you know, patting someone on the butt and rape or child molestation, right? Both of those behaviors need to be confronted and eradicated without question, but they shouldn’t be conflated, right?”

headline: Theresa May’s Deputy Resigns in Furor Over Porn on Work Computer
text: LONDON — Britain’s prime minister, Theresa May, suffered a new and damaging setback on Wednesday when a close and trusted ally, Damian Green, was forced to resign his cabinet post, after an investigation found that he misled the public about pornography found on his parliamentary computer.

headline: Mexico Graft Inquiry Deepens With Arrest of a Presidential Ally
text: CHIHUAHUA, Mexico — A former deputy in President Enrique Peña Nieto’s party has been arrested as part of an investigation into the illegal use of public money to fuel his party’s campaigns in Mexican elections last year, state officials announced on Wednesday.

headline: Mamie Johnson, Trailblazer in the Negro Leagues, Dies at 82
text: Mamie Johnson, one of a handful of women to play in baseball’s Negro leagues in the early 1950s — and the only one known to pitch — died on Monday in a Washington hospital. She was 82.

headline: How to Write Off Donations Under the New Tax Plan: Consider ‘Bunching’
text: The tax plan approved by Congress nearly doubles the standard deduction for individuals and families. That could simplify the filing process for millions of Americans, but it will complicate the giving strategies for many who have made a habit of deducting their charitable contributions.

headline: New York Hot Dogs in a Corn Dog State
text: Time was when any New York politician with a grain of ambition had to show reverence for the three I’s. That would be Ireland, Italy and Israel. For anyone aspiring to high office, visiting those lands was almost as fundamental as breathing, and a balanced citywide ticket contained descendants of each I. So you had carefully assembled combos like O’Dwyer, Joseph and Impellitteri (Democrats, 1945) and Lefkowitz, Fino and Gilhooley (Republicans, 1961).

headline: Rolling Stone Publisher Sells Majority Stake to Penske, Owner of Variety
text: Penske Media Corporation has acquired a controlling stake in Wenner Media, the publisher of the famed Rolling Stone magazine, the companies announced on Wednesday.

headline: In Tax Overhaul, Trump Tries to Defy the Economic Odds
text: When President  Trump adds his distinctive signature to the tax bill, he will also be making a huge bet that the Republican strategy of deep cuts for businesses and wealthy individuals will fuel extraordinary growth across the board.

headline: Enes Kanter Shrugs Off News That Turkey Wants to Jail Him
text: Enes Kanter is one of the more outspoken players in the N.B.A., riffing about LeBron James or Kevin Durant or just about anything else that grabs his attention.

headline: NFL Network Executive Resigns After Reports of Sexually Explicit Tweets
text: David Eaton, a top executive with the NFL Network, resigned a little more than a week after the league-owned sports channel came under fire for tolerating a hostile work environment for female employees.

headline: Justices Return Dispute Over DACA Documents to Lower Courts
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court indicated on Wednesday that federal courts in California had moved too fast in ordering the Trump administration to disclose documents concerning its decision to end a program that protected some 800,000 young, undocumented immigrants from deportation.

headline: Great Journalism Made Better With a Great (International) Audience
text: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.

headline: ‘The Hurt Is Still There’: Abuse Survivors Grapple With Cardinal’s Death
text: BOSTON — News of the death of Cardinal Bernard F. Law, who failed to remove sexually abusive priests from the ministry when he was archbishop of Boston, drew a sulfurous outcry in his old archdiocese on Wednesday from survivors still in pain from having been betrayed by the church they trusted.

headline: U.S. Banks Make Progress on Their Living Wills
text: American banks have finally got the hang of dying in their living wills. The Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation cleared the resolution plans of the eight biggest lenders on Tuesday, though four, including Wells Fargo, need improvements. It’s a far cry from 2016 when five failed outright.

headline: Venezuela Puts Up Roadblock for Opposition in Next Presidential Vote
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela’s Constituent Assembly, the political body created by President Nicolás Maduro as an end run around the legislature, on Wednesday made it harder for opposition politicians to run for president.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Savoring a Major Win in a Year of Setbacks
text: “This has been a year of extraordinary accomplishment for the Trump administration.”

headline: Corrections: December 21, 2017
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Fearful of a Shutdown, Congress Inches Toward Stopgap Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON — An end-of-the-year showdown that was once promised over delicate issues like immigration, health care and surveillance appeared to fizzle on Wednesday as key Republicans dropped their demands to shore up shaky health insurance markets and Democrats appeared to abandon their goal to force adoption of a measure protecting young undocumented immigrants from deportation.

headline: Law Requires Life-Saving Braking Device. Most Trains Don’t Have It.
text: On a summer afternoon in Southern California nine years ago, a commuter train blew through a stop signal and ran head-on into an oncoming freight train, killing 25 people.

headline: North Korean Soldier Defects Through DMZ, and Gunfire Erupts
text: HONG KONG — A North Korean soldier defected to South Korea on Thursday through the heavily guarded demilitarized zone separating the two countries, leading to gunfire on both sides of the border, the South Korean military said.

headline: A Judgment Day Cardinal Law Can’t Avoid
text: “Mom, why wasn’t I baptized?”

headline: Confederate Statues in Memphis Are Removed After City Council Vote
text: MEMPHIS — The City Council here voted Wednesday to sell two city parks with Confederate monuments, clearing the way for two statues to be removed before the city commemorates the 50th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: President Commutes Sentence of Iowa Meatpacking Executive
text: President Trump on Wednesday commuted the prison sentence of Sholom Rubashkin, whose Iowa meatpacking plant was the target of a huge immigration raid in 2008, and whose 27-year prison sentence angered many Orthodox Jews.

headline: Words of Understanding
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to a turning point in time, or its eve, depending on when you’re reading this. It is either the shortest or longest day of the year where you are, so whatever day-length slope that you’ve been on lately is just about to reverse itself. For me, in the Northern Hemisphere, that’s reason to celebrate as I enjoy more daylight hours.

headline: With Overdoses on Rise, Cities and Counties Look for Someone to Blame
text: AKRON, Ohio — Citing a spike in overdose deaths, growing demands for drug treatment and a strained budget, officials here in Summit County filed a lawsuit late Wednesday against companies that make or distribute prescription opioids. On Monday, Smith County in Tennessee did the same. And on Tuesday, nine cities and counties in Michigan announced similar suits.

headline: Eight Americans Among the Dead in Mexican Bus Crash
text: MEXICO CITY — Eight Americans were among 12 people killed Tuesday when a tourist bus traveling to visit Mayan ruins in southeastern Mexico ran off the road and flipped over, the American Embassy in Mexico City said Wednesday.

headline: Mets Give Sandy Alderson a New Contract
text: Sandy Alderson will return for, at least, his eighth season as the Mets’ general manager, after officially agreeing to a long-expected new contract, the team announced in a statement on Wednesday night.

headline: Instagram Is Now a Dating Platform, Too. Here’s How It Works.
text: Last April, Roberto Forgione noticed that someone who had ghosted him was looking at his Instagram Stories — the brief, casual updates that hang around for 24 hours at the top of the app’s screen and include lists of the people who have seen them.

headline: Most Lethal to Journalists: 1. War Zones 2. Mexico
text: Assassins on a motorcycle shot Cecilio Pineda Birto as he awaited his vehicle at a carwash, hitting him at least 10 times. Gunmen blocked the car of Javier Valdez Cárdenas after he left work, pumping at least 12 bullets into him. Miroslava Breach Velducea, leaving home with one of her children, was shot eight times by an unidentified assailant and died en route to the hospital.

headline: Catalonia Election Gives Separatists New Lift
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Spain’s effort to snuff out an independence drive in Catalonia was dealt a significant blow on Thursday as secessionists narrowly won an election called by Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy in hopes of calming the country’s constitutional crisis.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Peaky Blinders’ and ‘Great News’
text: Season 4 of “Peaky Blinders,” the gangster show starring Cillian Murphy and Adrien Brody, comes to Netflix. And “Great News” runs its Christmas episode.

headline: Melbourne Car Attack Was Not Connected to Terrorism, Police Say
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The driver of an S.U.V. who plowed into a crowd on a busy Melbourne street on Thursday, injuring 19 people, was mentally ill, Australian officials said, describing the attack as a deliberate “act of evil” but not terrorism.

headline: Word + Quiz: alcove
Combat Your Anxiety, One Step at a Time
text: Earlier this year, I suffered my first major panic attack. For days afterward, my heart would race and my mind would fill with doomsday visions as I worried about everything around me, including whether I’d have more panic attacks and if I’d ever be able to stop them.

text: China’s answer to Uber is catching up with its American rival in a key metric: money.

text: Should some movies dominated by male actors be remade with largely female casts? Or is doing so simply a concession to political correctness?

headline: Christmas Returns to a City Liberated From ISIS
text: After years of destruction in Qaraqosh, Iraq’s largest Christian enclave, residents are rebuilding and preparing for Christmas.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Curious Orangutans, Raised by Humans, Do Better on Cognitive Tests’
text: Before reading the article:

headline: Christmas Returns to a City Liberated From ISIS
text: For more than two years, 300 militia fighters waited to retake from the Islamic State the Iraqi city of Qaraqosh, the country’s largest Christian enclave. Then, in October of last year, the photographer Quentin Bruno accompanied these civilians turned soldiers as they approached the city that was once home to 50,000 people. He remembered their excitement, as well as the mortars that rained down upon them, a few days after the Iraqi Army had launched the Battle of Mosul.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Passport to Your National Parks’
text: I cringe at the thought that I might be patriotic, but the next thing I know, I’m trying on a Cheesehead hat at the airport in Milwaukee and thinking about how happy I am to live in a nation so vast and idiosyncratic. This, at least, is how I like to think of America — less a set of monolithic ideals than a junk drawer full of halftime shows, regional-style pizzas, feuds over what exactly to call “soda” and snippets of marches by John Philip Sousa. But that sort of patriotism, while good enough as entertainment, offers little comfort when I’m up late at night consuming my 25th hour of news. Lately, my America has felt too vast and fragmented, and fixating on regional curiosities like state-fair butter sculptures and St. Paul sandwiches only exacerbates this crisis of faith. I’ve been searching for new ways to keep liking this country, meaningful ways that don’t feel like work.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Photos of 2017?
text: What are the most memorable photographs you have seen in the news this year? What about them was so striking to you?

headline: Jakarta Is Sinking So Fast, It Could End Up Underwater
text: Countless human-made troubles in the Indonesian capital pose an imminent threat to the city’s survival. And it has to deal with mounting threats from climate change.

headline: 36 Hours in Manchester, England
text: A visit here becomes an exercise in peeling back layers of sooty, hard-working history to arrive at a shinier, bustling and hopeful present.

headline: A Luxury Vacation in Mexico, on a Budget
text: A luxurious vacation in Mexico doesn't have to come with a high price tag. Here's how to get, stay, and enjoy your time there on a budget.

headline: ‘The Crown’: The History Behind Season 2 on Netflix
text: Season 1 of “The Crown” on Netflix, about the life and times of Queen Elizabeth II, focused on the young monarch’s ascent to the throne and the effect that had on her relationships, particularly with her husband, Philip. Season 2, which debuted earlier this month, continues those themes while also exploring the role of the royal family within a fading empire and changing society.

headline: Francis Ford Coppola: By the Book
text: The filmmaker and author of “Live Cinema and Its Techniques” splits his reading among fiction, history, science, religion and philosophy, “rarely popular best sellers.”

headline: Starry, Starry Dust
text: Q. What is the cosmic dust that I keep hearing about? What is it made of? Where does it come from?

headline: In an Unforgiving Sport, They Minister to Hearts and Souls
text: The work is done over a quiet cup of coffee, in the privacy of the physiotherapist’s room, or through a brief chat on the touchline after training. It might be no more than a quick text message or email, asking if everything is O.K.

headline: Requiem for the Individual Mandate
text: The individual mandate, an idea inspired by conservative intellectuals but ultimately embraced by Democratic lawmakers as an essential part of the Affordable Care Act, will soon be dead. The provision would be eliminated under the tax bill passed on Wednesday.

headline: A Meal of Joyous Excess for the Holidays
text: If you had told me, back in my 20s, how great it would be to spend Christmas Eve cooking for family as someone rustles wrapping paper in the living room and the dog snores at my feet, I wouldn’t have believed you, would have scoffed like a Gen-X Scrooge. I was content then to hold up the bar with friends and strangers, to drain Rolling Rocks and sing “Fairytale of New York,” take a swing and a miss at the midnight service, then trudge the long walk home in the cold. I’m not any longer. I cook and serve others food that is both fantastical and rich, to allow all who eat it to sleep through whatever late-night shenanigans put gifts under the tree, and to rise in the morning Christmas-excited. My children are teenagers now. But I believe they still slightly believe. The dinner helps.

headline: In ‘Bethlehem,’ Tracing the Life of a Storied Little Town
text: BETHLEHEM Biography of a Town By Nicholas Blincoe Illustrated. 271 pp. Nation Books. $28.

headline: Inside the High-Drama World of Youth Competition Dance
text: The second time I met Angelina Velardi she had just lost a baby tooth. It left a gaping hole in her smile, but she liked how it looked: “Now if I show the judges I’m mature, they’ll be more impressed,” she said, happily. Angelina is a 12-year-old competitive dancer, and canny to the ways in which technical acuity and preadolescent pliability can be combined to her advantage. She started competitive dancing less than three years ago.

headline: In New Jersey, Searching for a Dog-Friendly Place to Call Their Own
text: Richard Pena and Lorena Flores met as students at Elizabeth High School in New Jersey.

headline: 12 Surprising Reasons to Be Grateful for the Arts in 2017
text: These 12 blink-and-you-might-have-missed-them cultural moments of 2017 brightened up a year otherwise defined by the threat of nuclear war, natural disasters — from hurricanes to wildfires — that left hundreds of thousands homeless, a string of sexual harassment charges against some of the country’s most prominent political and entertainment figures and yet more terrorist attacks. These are the small but indelible pleasures that our editors and reporters have been grateful for in the past year.

headline: Samantha Bee Looks for Omens in Trump’s Decision on Jerusalem
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Melbourne, Facebook, Winter Solstice: Your Thursday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: My Worst Columns
text: We journalists like to boast about how many clicks our stories get, or how our columns go viral. Fair enough, but today let me show off my clunkers.

headline: Why ‘The Graduate’ Is a Vietnam Movie
text: And here’s to you, Mrs. Robinson, for your part in stopping the Vietnam War. True, Anne Bancroft’s seductress was hardly known for her interest in foreign affairs. But the movie in which she starred left an indelible mark on the Vietnam generation. Though it avoided all mention of an overseas military conflict, “The Graduate,” which opened 50 years ago this month, surpassed every film of its era in connecting with the radically altered mood of American youth.

headline: Home From Harvard, Back in the Holiday Hot Seat
text: A few weeks ago, I called an Uber to take me to the Boston airport for a flight home for the holidays. As I slid into the back seat of the car, the warm intonations of the driver’s accent washed over me in a familiar way.

headline: Presidential Incapacity: A Holiday Gift Guide
text: Perfect last-minute choices for any person, inspired by Donald Trump, thinking about the history of the 25th Amendment.

headline: Why Judges Matter
text: The Trump administration’s increasingly bizarre war on abortion continues as immigration officials keep trying to block access to abortion for pregnant undocumented teenagers in their custody. The administration has no law on its side (leading career lawyers in the Justice Department to withhold their signatures from its legal pleadings) but still won’t stop exploiting the plight of these most vulnerable young women, for no apparent reason other than a commitment to saving the world one fetus at a time.

headline: The Great American Tax Heist
text: With their tax bill, Donald Trump and the Republicans are raiding the Treasury in plain sight, throwing crumbs to the masses as the millionaires and billionaires make off with the cake.

headline: Philippine Ferry Capsizes, but Vast Majority of Passengers Are Saved
text: Five people died when a ferry capsized in the Philippines on Thursday, the authorities said, renewing concerns about maritime safety in the archipelagic nation.

headline: Can a Fitness Tracker Help You Run a Better Race?
text: At the start of this year’s New York City Marathon, three people stared at me and tried to figure out why I didn’t have a heartbeat. I had one, of course. It just wasn’t registering on the puck-shaped device taped to my body that was part of Performance Metrics, a tracking system created by the marathon’s sponsor, TCS, and not commercially available. It was supposed to be able to spit out my heart rate, breathing rate, pace and speed in real time.

headline: Immortality at Midnight
text: Toward the end of another unexpected year of existence, outliving a poor prognosis of late-stage cancer rouses me in the dark. Such an awakening is quite different from the fretful insomnia that accompanied the dire diagnosis. Especially in this season of celebrated miracles, it somehow thrills me to be stirring at 2 or 3 a.m. Trepidation and grief dissolve in the weird awareness (can it possibly be true?) of still being alive.

headline: Read Up on Your New Year’s Resolutions Before You Begin
text: Let’s face it: 2017 has been a year when we could have all used help, whether in learning to live a little better, love a little better or just generally not be driven insane by our fellow man. Here are five of the most memorable books I reviewed in this year’s Help Desk.

headline: When They Met, She Was a Wreck. So Was He.
text: Sometimes in life’s worst moments, we realize how strong and resilient we truly are. And, in those moments, our vulnerability might allow magic to happen.

headline: New York Today: The Year in (Good) News
text: Good morning on this sunny-but-nippy winter solstice, the shortest day of the year.

headline: You Cannot Be Too Cynical About the Republican Tax Bill
text: The rush to enact the tax bill was designed to mask — as a break for the middle class — what is in fact a $1.4 trillion package of benefits for key donors and lobbyists, the richest members of Congress, President Trump, his family and other families like his.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Sexual Harassment at Ford
text: Decades after the company tried to tackle sexual misconduct at two plants, new allegations of abuse raise questions about the possibility of change.

text: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: ‘A Deliberate Act’ in Melbourne
text: A vehicle rammed into a crowd on a busy street in Australia, injuring 19. The police said that the driver’s motivation was not yet known but that they did not suspect terrorism.

headline: Review: In ‘A German Life,’ Goebbels’s Secretary Explains Her Actions
text: “A German Life” is likely to be the last new movie of its kind: a documentary that presents contemporary testimony from someone who witnessed the inner workings of the Nazi high command. The movie is taken from 30 hours of interviews with Brunhilde Pomsel, who served as a secretary to Joseph Goebbels and was 103 when the film was shot. (She died in January at 106.)

headline: Review: In ‘Hangman,’ Al Pacino Trails a Killer With a Unique Vocabulary
text: The most and least that can be said for “Hangman” is that it doesn’t approach the mesmerizing ineptitude of “88 Minutes,” another movie that pitted Al Pacino against a serial killer from about a decade ago. This time, the killer carves letters into the victims’ bodies, spelling out a message in a tribute to the children’s word game Hangman. The slick, music video-style opening credits — a staple of this genre since “Seven” — include an ominous box of crayons.

headline: Review: ‘Along With the Gods’ Is a Fantasy Journey With C.G.I. at Every Turn
text: Kim Yong-hwa’s delirious fantasy “Along With the Gods: The Two Worlds” is a harmless romp flirting at profundity without coming close. But it certainly offers plenty to occupy the eye. Rarely has a director so reveled in the possibilities of digital effects (with the exception of Robert Rodriguez during his “Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl” period). That said, story clarity and emotional depth tend to evaporate amid the visual pyrotechnics.

headline: Review: A ‘Crooked House’ of Murder and Resentment
text: The premise of the murder mystery “Crooked House” is old school: A much-loathed patriarch is sent to his grave, and a houseful of resentful, back-stabbing kinfolk are under suspicion. This intermittently diverting movie is adapted from a 1949 Agatha Christie novel, and it’s several degrees more engaging than another recent Christie-based movie, “Murder on the Orient Express.” But it’s still slight.

headline: Review: ‘Drawing Home’ Sketches the Life of an Artist Couple
text: “Drawing Home” takes place amid golden-needled pines, aquamarine lakes and warm firelight, all against the palette of gray rock and white snow that is the Canadian Rockies. A more stunning film landscape than this one, Canada’s Banff National Park in Alberta, is hard to find.

headline: Facial Scans at U.S. Airports Violate Americans’ Privacy, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — A new report concludes that a Department of Homeland Security pilot program improperly gathers data on Americans when it requires passengers embarking on foreign flights to undergo facial recognition scans to ensure they haven’t overstayed visas.

headline: 2017 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: The Playoff Paths That Remain for Every Team
text: Exploring the playoff chances and seeding possibilities with two weeks to go.

headline: Eric Schmidt, Alphabet’s ‘Ambassador,’ to Step Down: DealBook Briefing
text: Good Thursday. Here’s what we’re watching:

headline: 10 Models Who Caught Our Eye This Year
text: We first met the Brazilian-born and Switzerland-bred Oliveira in February, when she was named one of our models to watch at the fall/winter 2017 shows. (She told T that she likes to spend her time backstage “making everyone laugh,” instead of being “on another planet with headphones in, so I always talk and get to know people.”) In August, Oliveira posed for her inaugural T shoot, an editorial that dissected the contemporary punk trend.

headline: Small-Batch Botanical Oils, Made in Brooklyn
text: Lately, talk at my Brooklyn-based book group inevitably turns not to the moral and aesthetic implications of preventive Botox, as it once did, but to oils — who is saving up for a bottle of Vintner’s Daughter, a cult favorite California-made face oil, and who is blending their own concoctions with extracts procured from an online retailer called Mountain Rose Herbs that specializes in organically grown ingredients for aspiring aromatherapists and facialists.

headline: Where Winter’s Silver Skates Warmed the Soul
text: The surprising thing about Frances A. Rosenfeld’s extremely tall map of New York City is that the lake in Central Park is not first or second or even third. It is merely No. 4.

headline: 6 Holiday Toy Crazes and Why They Captivated Kids (and Parents)
text: Buying children’s gifts for the holidays is a perilous process. A doll or a phonics book? A miniature fire truck or a wooden robot that teaches 3-year-olds how to code?

text: Good morning.

headline: Taking Health Care From Kids
text: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: Renters Are Staying Put
text: Only 21.7 percent of renters moved in 2017, a historically low rate, according to newly released United States Census Bureau data. Homeowners moved at an even lower rate — 5.5 percent, a slight uptick from 2016.

headline: Governor Cuomo Proposes More Disclosure for Online Political Ads in New York
text: ALBANY — Following a federal push for more disclosure, and amid investigations into Russian meddling into American elections, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is proposing legislation to close legal loopholes in New York regarding political ads on the internet, with the goal of pressuring companies like Facebook to root out foreign-based interlopers in online campaigns.

headline: Review: In ‘Happy End,’ Another Unhappy Family From Michael Haneke
text: If you are even only a little familiar with the work of the Austrian filmmaker Michael Haneke, it will come as no surprise that he does not regard instant messaging and smartphones as positive developments for humanity. His latest picture, “Happy End,” begins with the middle of its wide-screen frame taken up by the perfectly centered image of a phone, its camera eavesdropping on a middle-age woman whose bathroom door is open as she prepares for bed. The unseen voyeur texts snide commentary on the woman’s routine.

headline: Using Android to Convert Pixels to Paper
text: Q. I can print documents directly from my iPad to a Hewlett-Packard wireless printer over my home network. Can I print from a new Android device to this same printer, too?

headline: Review: ‘Hostiles’ Grapples With the Contradictions of the Western
text: “Hostiles” opens with a well-traveled observation from D.H. Lawrence about how the “essential American soul is hard, isolate, stoic and a killer.” It ends with a shot that complicates that idea by revisiting and in effect reversing a famous image from an earlier western: The last moment of “The Searchers,” when John Wayne lingers outside the door, symbolically barred from entering the civilized society he has saved.

headline: Yes, You Really Can Pay for Private School With 529 Plans Now
text: So it actually happened.

headline: New Trailer: ‘Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again,’ Starring Cher
text: “Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again.” Some critics may be saying the same thing, but the original “Mamma Mia,” despite mixed reviews, became the highest-grossing movie musical ever when it was released in 2008, grossing more than $600 million worldwide. A decade later, along comes a sequel, and the first trailer has just been released.

headline: Town Fears G.O.P. Tax Plan Will Erode Its Egalitarian Pillars
text: COLUMBIA, Md. — The word “equality” carries special meaning in this planned community, nestled in the corridor between Baltimore and Washington.

headline: Review: In ‘Downsizing,’ Matt Damon Sweats the Small Stuff
text: One of my favorite movies of 2017, “War for the Planet of the Apes,” posited near-total human extinction as a more-or-less happy ending. A radically dystopian future seems like the best we deserve these days, and it was impressive to see a summer blockbuster offer such harsh medicine.

headline: Tax Cuts Buoy Republicans, but They’re Swimming Against an Undertow
text: WASHINGTON — The sweeping tax overhaul approved by Congress this week hands Republicans a long-sought achievement they believe will bolster their defenses in next year’s midterm campaign, but party officials concede the measure may only mitigate their losses in what is shaping up to be a punishing election year.

headline: Owners of the Sabres Add N.W.H.L.’s Beauts to Buffalo Stable
text: The owners of the Buffalo Sabres have purchased the Buffalo Beauts of the National Women’s Hockey League, becoming the second N.H.L. ownership group this season to buy into a professional women’s hockey franchise.

headline: Grace, a Celebrated Chicago Restaurant, Closes After Its Founders Leave
text: Grace, a Chicago restaurant considered to be one of America’s best places to dine, closed abruptly on Wednesday after the chef and the general manager announced they were no longer working there.

headline: Australia Finds Wreck of World War I Submarine, Solving a 103-Year Enigma
text: LONDON — For more than a century, the fate of Australia’s first military submarine was one of the country’s enduring maritime mysteries.

headline: On the Surface and Underneath, a Syrian Boy Carries the Scars of War
text: GHAZZE, Lebanon — Amal Ismail El-Suleiman dropped a handful of creams and ointments on the floor of her home. They were just a few of the more than 15 she had tried on the skin disease that has covered her son Sariya’s face over the past four years.

headline: 17 Postcards From Our Correspondents Around the World in 2017
text: Correspondents for The New York Times reported from more than 140 countries this year, covering war, terrorism, political upheaval, natural disaster and social change. But they also found stories about searching for mussels beneath the ice in northern Quebec, about Italian pizzamakers recognized for their intangible contributions to human culture, and about running the Beirut marathon.

headline: Review: ‘Bright’ Has Fairies, Orcs, Elves and L.A. Cops, but Little Magic
text: With the buddy-cop fantasy “Bright,” Will Smith and the director David Ayer attempt to chart new territory: an urban action film populated not only by humans but also fantastical creatures like centaurs, fairies, orcs and elves. (If you’re unfamiliar with orcs, check your J. R. R. Tolkien.) The result is a loud, ungainly hybrid that does not serve police procedurals or fantasy spectaculars very well.

text: WASHINGTON — Congress gave final approval on Thursday to legislation to keep the government funded into January, averting a government shutdown this weekend but kicking fights over issues like immigration, surveillance and health care into the new year.

headline: Apple Is the Most Valuable Public Company Ever. But How Much of a Record Is That?
text: Its market capitalization is now worth more than the entire G.D.P. of Turkey, and last month, when adjusting for inflation, pushed past Microsoft’s high point set during the height of the dotcom boom.

headline: Depicting, and Respecting, the Dead: Responses to Photos From Mount Everest
text: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

headline: Carmakers Try to Keep Waste Out of the Ground as Well as the Air
text: FLINT, Mich. — Mammoth bins and barrels line the edge of a General Motors factory floor, stuffed with industrial detritus like shavings of aluminum, pieces of plastic and glass and chemical sludge that has come off the machines that are used to assemble engines for three models of Chevrolet. Every bit of it, G.M. promises, has a future.

headline: Santa Is a Psychedelic Mushroom
text: It’s time to embrace the shamanistic side of Christmas.

headline: Feliĉa Ferioj! Toasting the Holidays in Esperanto
text: “Saluton,” was how members of the Esperanto Society of New York greeted each other as they arrived at their holiday party in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Santa Is a Psychedelic Mushroom
text: It’s the holiday season, and I’m thinking of mushrooms. The hallucinogenic Amanita muscaria to be exact — a red-and-white toadstool mushroom — most closely associated with fairy tales. At first glance, Amanita muscaria and the Christmas holiday appear to be an unlikely duo. But would it be too far-fetched to propose that the story of our modern Santa Claus, the omnipotent man who travels the globe in one night, bearing gifts, and who’s camped out in shopping malls across the United States this month, is linked to a hallucinogenic mushroom-eating shaman from the Arctic?

headline: Five Takeaways From a Year of Talking About Race
text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Lynn Nottage on the story of race and Appalachia. The restaurateur and author Eddie Huang on racial stereotypes and diversity in Hollywood. Leon and Rosina Watson on marrying across the color line in 1950 — when it was still illegal in much of the country.

headline: The Week in Good News: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, Lightsabers and Roman Treasures
text: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart.

headline: How to Tell the Olds You’ve Outgrown Christmas
text: I’m 12 years old, and every adult I meet assumes that I’m really excited about Christmas — mostly, about getting presents. But I’m not. I used to love it when I was little, but now I don’t really need (or want) anything. We aren’t religious in my family, so the Bethlehem part seems kind of random. When my parents’ friends say, “I bet you’re counting the days till Christmas,” what should I do? Tell the truth and look like a freak, or just go along with it?

headline: South Korean Building Fire Kills Dozens
text: A fire that spread through an eight-story building in the South Korean city of Jecheon left at least 29 people dead on Thursday, according to fire officials. Dozens more were injured by the blaze.

headline: Defying Trump, U.N. General Assembly Condemns U.S. Decree on Jerusalem
text: UNITED NATIONS — A lopsided majority of United Nations members rebuked the United States on Thursday, denouncing its decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s capital and ignoring President Trump’s threats to retaliate by cutting aid to countries voting against it.

headline: Janet Elder, a Top Editor at The Times, Dies at 61
text: Janet Elder, who in a three-decade career at The New York Times rose from reporter to deputy managing editor, along the way spending many years as the editor of news surveys and election analysis, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 61.

headline: Victims of Guatemala’s Civil War Are Laid to Rest, 3 Decades Later
text: SANTA AVELINA, Guatemala — Juana García Gómez, 75, wept over two coffins placed side by side in the sports hall of the Santa Avelina school in the western highlands of Guatemala.

headline: In Reversal, Düsseldorf Will Hold Exhibition About Jewish Dealer
text: After intense criticism, the mayor of Düsseldorf has backtracked on his last-minute cancellation of an exhibition at the city’s Stadtmuseum about Max Stern, a Jewish art gallery owner who fled Nazi Germany in 1938.

headline: Agrarian Kitchen Offers a Tasmanian Fantasy
text: A breezy interior and farm-fresh dishes are at odds with the surrounding ruins of a mental hospital.

headline: Review: the Agrarian Kitchen Eatery & Store in New Norfolk, Tasmania
text: NEW NORFOLK, Tasmania — There may be no restaurant in all of Tasmania as bright and airy, as brimming with good feeling, as the Agrarian Kitchen Eatery & Store. The long room’s impossibly high pressed-tin ceilings and white-painted walls manage that elusory meeting of modernity and rusticism — simplicity at its most luxurious.

headline: JPMorgan ‘Seriously Breached’ Money-Laundering Rules, Swiss Regulator Says
text: Switzerland’s financial regulator said JPMorgan Chase’s Swiss subsidiary “seriously breached” anti-money laundering rules by completing transactions with a Malaysian government investment fund that is under investigation in at least six countries.

headline: Queen Elizabeth Letters Show Her Distrust of Mary Queen of Scots
text: LONDON — Forty-three letters written by Queen Elizabeth I, her chief minister Lord Burghley and her secretary of state, Sir Francis Walsingham, have been donated to the American Trust for the British Library by Mark Pigott, an American businessman. Mr. Pigott, whose company, Paccar, donated $1.35 million to the British Library in 2008, had previously lent the letters to the library after buying them at an auction in 2010, for around $400,000.

headline: Review: In ‘The Post,’ Democracy Survives the Darkness
text: Steven Spielberg’s exhilarating drama “The Post” is about a subject that’s dear to the heart of journalists: themselves! Set largely during a few anxious weeks in 1971, it revisits The Washington Post’s decision to publish portions of the Pentagon Papers, an immense classified report that chronicled America’s involvement in Southeast Asia from World War II to 1968. In Mr. Spielberg’s hands, that decision becomes a ticktock thriller about the freedom of the press, the White House’s war on that constitutional right and the middle-aged woman who defended freedom in a fabulous gold caftan.

headline: What Are Some Good TV Romances?
text: Are you trying to figure out what to watch next? (Or maybe what TV show to give up on completely?) Watching is here to help. Send your questions to watching@nytimes.com.

headline: Remaking Ancient Greece, With Paints or Pixels
text: The Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, a branch of New York University ensconced in a townhouse off Fifth Avenue, is an academic institution that welcomes doctoral students and visiting scholars and hosts small, concentrated exhibitions of antiquities from Greece, Rome, Byzantium and Persia. It is not where one usually comes to encounter contemporary video art, still less a work featuring complex 3D graphics, a pulsing electronica score, and captions in hot-pink Helvetica.

headline: When Trump Vilifies Legal Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Benefits of Letting Students Mess Up
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dr. Goodwin on the Phone
text: Listen to one of Dr. Goodwin’s calls with a hotline, in which he says he’s looking for treatment for his marijuana use.

headline: Shell, Seeking to Curb Its Carbon Footprint, Buys Electricity Provider
text: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell announced on Thursday that it had agreed to buy a Britain-based provider of electrical power and natural gas, one of the boldest in a series of recent investments in non-oil and gas-energy businesses by large European oil companies.

headline: Harassed at Work? Advice on What to Do
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is Apple Slowing Down Old iPhones? Questions and Answers
text: For years, some consumers have suspected Apple of a nefarious plot: The company, they said, was slowing down their older iPhones to get them to buy new ones. Now, many of them feel vindicated.

headline: How Lincoln Center Was Built (It Wasn’t Pretty)
text: Q. How many people were displaced by the construction of Lincoln Center, and what happened to them?

headline: The Four Threats to Robert Mueller
text: At least for the moment, it seems that Robert Mueller, the special counsel, may keep his job. President Trump declared this week that he does not currently intend to fire him — a concession, perhaps, to the overwhelming public opposition to such a move. But that doesn’t mean Mr. Mueller’s investigation is free from peril. The inquiry remains in great danger, facing four looming threats from Mr. Trump and his allies.

headline: Wartime, Law Time and a Stop by the Park
text: “No one would ever confuse me with a saint,” Rick Ledbetter admits after deifying his younger brother, Tommy. “I’m pretty sure murderers don’t qualify.”

headline: Eggs, Tomatoes and a Quick Trip to Purgatory
text: It used to be that whenever I craved a bowl of runny-yolked eggs poached in red sauce, I’d whip up some shakshuka. I first tasted this North African dish, made from stewed tomatoes, onions, sweet peppers and plenty of spices, on a trip to Israel, where it’s extremely popular, and have been hooked ever since.

headline: Jerusalem, South Korea, Melbourne: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: 5 Great Art Exhibitions to See in New York Before They Close
text: The winter holidays get a bit frantic, and not just with gift-buying and related rituals. All those art exhibitions you’ve been meaning to see for months are closing soon. Don’t panic — one strategy is to use art-viewing to mitigate the holiday stresses. Here are some worthwhile shows that may have escaped your notice and will all close after New Year’s (with one gallery exhibition that ends sooner). These worthy shows may just rekindle your stamina.

headline: Journalist Charged With Rioting at Inauguration Day Protest Goes Free
text: Alexei Wood, a journalist who was arrested while covering a protest of Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, was found not guilty at the Superior Court of the District of Columbia on Thursday of all seven counts against him, including conspiracy to riot and several counts of destruction of property. Mr. Wood had originally faced up to 61 years in prison.

headline: Federal Officials Reportedly Investigating Group Where Women Were Branded
text: The Justice Department has started an investigation into a self-described self-help group in which women were branded with a symbol containing its leader’s initials, several people contacted as part of the inquiry said.

headline: Get Me to a Nunnery
text: Three years ago this week, I was a guest at a cloistered Catholic abbey in rural Connecticut. I spent my days in near-silence, waking before dawn for Mass, working the farm alongside nuns in full habit. When bells rang at regular intervals, all work ceased so that the nuns could chant in Latin.

headline: For Sore Throat, Xylitol and Probiotics Offer No Benefits Over Placebo
text: Xylitol, a popular sweetener in sugarless gum, and probiotics are sometimes recommended as remedies for sore throat, but a randomized trial has found that neither works better than a placebo.

headline: Stressed New Yorkers Take to Kava, ‘Nature’s Xanax’
text: By day, Brooklyn Kava is like any Brooklyn cafe. A flood of commuters leaving Bushwick in the morning stops in for coffee, and the rush ebbs and flows throughout the day with a diverse set of artists, students, and workers between shifts.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 52 People and Entities for Abuse and Corruption
text: WASHINGTON — The United States imposed sanctions on 52 people and entities Thursday for alleged human rights violations and corruption, a list that included Maung Maung Soe, a top Burmese general cited for an ongoing deadly crackdown on the Rohingya, a Muslim ethnic group.

headline: Mortgage Giants Cut Deal With Treasury to Cover Expected Losses
text: WASHINGTON — Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-controlled mortgage finance giants rescued during the financial crisis, reached a deal with the Treasury Department on Thursday allowing them to keep some of their profits as they brace for losses that will be activated by the tax bill soon to be signed by President Trump.

headline: Vitaly Mutko Said to Be Stepping Down From Russia World Cup Role
text: LONDON — Vitaly Mutko, Russia’s deputy prime minister and a longtime sports official for the country, may soon relinquish his role as leader of the organizing committee for next summer’s World Cup after drawing intense scrutiny for his role in Russia’s state-supported doping program.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
text: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: Combat Jack, Hip-Hop Lawyer Turned Podcast Pioneer, Dies at 53
text: Reggie Ossé, a knowledgeable and boisterous broadcasting personality better known as Combat Jack who parlayed his experience in hip-hop into a podcasting empire, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 53.

headline: Holiday Windows Brighten a Bleak Retail Scene, but How Long Will They Last?
text: One of my fondest childhood memories is of my family’s annual holiday trip to St. Louis to see the department store windows. I was transfixed by the corner window at Famous-Barr, where model trains wound their way through a labyrinth of tunnels and bridges in a snow-covered mountain landscape.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Post’ Shows an Empire Awash in Adultery and Gin and Tonics
text: The fall of the British Empire and the rise of Arab nationalism have rarely looked as ravishing as they do in “The Last Post,” a highly scenic evocation of the days of gin and tonics at the club and discreet bed-hopping in the officers’ quarters.

headline: Duck and Lentils: Deep Flavor for the Depths of Winter
text: I like beans all year round, but I especially appreciate them in winter. A plate of pinto beans studded with hunks of smoky, long-cooked bacon, for me, is a special feast. Or cannellini beans stewed with olive oil and herbs, or a steaming bowl of spicy black bean soup. I’m a lentil fan, too. I like them in nearly any guise, from any of the world’s cuisines.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
text: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: Despite Internal Review, Justice Department Officials Say Congress Needs to Act on Bump Stocks
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Department officials have indicated they do not believe the department can regulate the sale of gun bump stocks without congressional action, underscoring concern that an ongoing administrative review into that question is little more than an effort to slow-roll a politically divisive issue.

headline: M.L.B. Executive Ousted for Inappropriate Behavior
text: Bob Bowman, a powerful Major League Baseball executive credited with generating extraordinary revenue for the league, was forced out by baseball’s commissioner because of a pattern of inappropriate behavior going back at least 10 years, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

headline: Classical Music in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

headline: Comedy in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

headline: Dance in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to dance performances.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: Two (big) books of poems by the same poet kick off our list of recommendations this week: a pair of volumes of “The Complete Poems of A. R. Ammons,” by a two-time winner of the National Book Award who died at 75 in 2001. You might also want to take a look at two new books about comics (by different authors) — “Cartoon County,” a memoir by Cullen Murphy, the son of the artist behind the strip “Prince Valiant”; and “Why Comics?,” Hillary L. Chute’s wide-ranging look at how and why the medium has become so popular. There’s more, including a novel set during the French Resistance, a memoir of being held captive by the Taliban and the diaries Tina Brown kept during her years atop Vanity Fair.
