headline: On the Dance Beat: Extreme Focus, Extreme Costumes, Extreme Imagination
text: It has become routine to talk about mindfulness, but as a dance writer, I’ve been putting it into practice for years. That’s what you do when you watch a dance. You focus your total awareness on the present.

headline: New Year’s Eve, Iran, Donald Trump: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Laughter, Then Horror, as Flames Engulfed Upscale Mumbai Restaurants
text: MUMBAI, India — Aksheeta Doshi Shroff and a few family members were relaxing at 1 Above, a rooftop restaurant in a trendy district of Mumbai, when a small fire broke out shortly after midnight on Friday.

headline: In Congo, 8 Killed and Altar Boys Arrested Amid Crackdown on Protests
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — At least eight people were killed and a dozen altar boys arrested in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Sunday after security forces cracked down on planned church protests against President Joseph Kabila’s refusal to leave office before coming elections.

headline: Even in Poland, Workers’ Wages Flow to North Korea
text: POLICE, Poland — At an isolated shipyard on Poland’s Baltic coast, men in coveralls used welding torches under a cold drizzle, forging an oil tanker for a customer in the Netherlands. The scene was unremarkable, save for the provenance of a dozen of the workers.

headline: Passing the Torch to the Next Generation of Volunteers
text: James Robinson was explaining how he ended up in his own ambulance, not in front at the wheel, but in the back, injured.

headline: Colorado Gunman Shoots 5 Officers Near Denver, One Fatally
text: It began as a predawn call for the police to a disturbance at an apartment complex in a Denver suburb on Sunday. It ended, officials said, in a fusillade of more than 100 rounds fired by a barricaded gunman who shot five law enforcement officers, killing one of them. The gunman was killed by officers.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 17 at Funeral in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber walked into a cemetery in eastern Afghanistan on Sunday and blew himself up during the funeral of a local official, killing at least 17 people and wounding 14 others, an official said.

headline: Merkel’s Wishes for 2018: More Empathy and a New Government
text: BERLIN — Angela Merkel of Germany, addressing her country as an acting chancellor, pledged in her annual New Year’s address on Sunday to work for all Germans and to swiftly form a new government to help ensure success into 2018 and beyond.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: Fire Department Finds a Way Around Times Square Traffic for Medical Emergencies
text: An ambulance, with its siren wailing and lights flashing, was unable to move, stuck in gridlocked traffic one recent afternoon along Eighth Avenue in Times Square. Some drivers tried to get out of the way even as pedestrians hurried past. But it was too late. The light changed and vehicles from a nearby street spilled onto the clogged roadway, causing further congestion.

headline: After 2nd Bout With Cancer, Seeking to Heal His Body and Mind
text: Because he was in such a hurry to get to his granddaughter’s high school graduation, James Riddick did not realize he had forgotten his cane until he reached the bus.

headline: The Acrobatic Artwork That Pretty Much Sums Up 2017
text: Every once in a while with Twitter, you find something that breaks through the bilge and recrimination. Or, sometimes something finds you. One night, “The Mechanics of History” found me. It’s an art installation by Yoann Bourgeois that sat in a daylit rotunda at the Panthéon, in Paris. And for a long while in late fall, I found myself mesmerized by a video of it, starring men spinning off a staircase and onto a trampoline.

headline: Rohingya Children Facing ‘Massive Mental Health Crisis’
text: BALUKHALI, Bangladesh — Jehora Begum was a fast runner, racing through rice paddies and splashing through canals.

headline: The Month in Live Jazz: 5 Standout Shows
text: The true way to experience improvised music is live. More than in most other art forms, jazz’s big discoveries and developments have historically happened onstage: The music’s creation depends on an engaged, participating audience. With that in mind, we’re starting this column, recapping the most outstanding live jazz performances I’ve seen over the past month. I’m hoping that it will offer some clues as to where jazz is headed these days — and maybe even encourage you to go out and hear it for yourself.

headline: Charles Dutoit Replaced at New York Philharmonic Concerts After Assault Allegations
text: Joshua Weilerstein will conduct a series of New York Philharmonic concerts in January, after Charles Dutoit stepped down from the podium following sexual assault allegations.

headline: Ringo Starr Tapped for Knighthood
text: Ringo Starr has been named a knight. The Beatles drummer was selected for knighthood by Queen Elizabeth II in her 2018 New Year’s Honors list, along with Barry Gibb of the Bee Gees and the author Michael Morpurgo. The ballet dancer Darcey Bussell has been named a dame.

headline: Manchester City Avoids Defeat but Not Injuries
text: LONDON — After a record run of 18 successive wins in the Premier League, only a penalty save in stoppage time enabled Manchester City to escape its first defeat of the season Sunday at 17th-place Crystal Palace.

headline: We Will Carry You
text: Australia Diary is a weekly collection of reader stories (and images and videos) reflecting Australia’s unique character. Share yours with us and check out our previous installments.

headline: Dan Talbot, Impresario of Art Films, Is Dead at 91
text: Dan Talbot, one of the most influential figures in the world of art-house film as an operator of Manhattan theaters — including Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, which is scheduled to close on Jan. 28 — and a founder of the film distribution company New Yorker Films, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Review: Ending the Year With a Pair of Early-Music Ensembles
text: Two of New York’s established early-music ensembles plied specialties over the weekend, a study in contrasts despite basic similarities.

headline: New Slaughtering Rules Pit Dutch Religious Freedoms Against Animal Rights
text: AMSTERDAM — For 60 years, the Sal Meyer deli in Amsterdam has been serving kosher foods like its signature pekelvlees, a fatty corned beef steeped in meat juices and served with a bun.

headline: Cruise Ships Have Made Bar Harbor Popular. But Have They Ruined It?
text: BAR HARBOR, Me. — Residents of this scenic coastal town have struggled for the last several years with a conundrum familiar to anyone living in a beautiful place that attracts tourists: How do you maintain its essence when crowds threaten the very qualities they come to enjoy?

headline: ‘Last Jedi’ Is 2017’s Box Office Winner in a Women-Led Year
text: LOS ANGELES — Sorry, Batman. So close, yet so far away, Star-Lord. Better luck next time, Captain Jack Sparrow.

headline: Tax Law Offers a Carrot to Gig Workers. But It May Have Costs.
text: The new tax law is likely to accelerate a hotly disputed trend in the American economy by rewarding workers who sever formal relationships with their employers and become contractors.

headline: Sabres Return to Spotlight for the Winter Classic’s 10th Anniversary
text: Buffalo, which hosted the first Classic, has struggled in the 10 years since the game became a New Year’s Day staple.

headline: Louisiana Man Charged in ‘Nigerian Prince’ Scheme
text: The “Nigerian prince” letter, one of the better-known frauds, is often perpetrated by mysterious figures. But the police in Louisiana say they’ve put a face and a name to a man and charged him with more than 200 counts related to the scheme.

headline: From Trump to #MeToo: A Dizzying Year in TV News
text: A cable-news-obsessed president turned TV journalists into household names. A nationwide reckoning on sexual harassment ended the careers of some of television’s best-known personalities. And Americans, seeking clarity amid the noise, turned to networks like Fox News and MSNBC in record numbers. Two New York Times media reporters analyze 2017, the year when TV roared back.

headline: How Do You Turn an Ad Into a Meme? Two Words: Dilly Dilly
text: In 1995, a nation was rapt as three frogs croaked the syllables in “Budweiser.” Four years later, Budweiser prompted countless television viewers to wag their tongues and ask their friends, “Whassup?”

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: ‘Goddess of Anarchy’
text: Lucy Parsons would stand out today, so one can imagine the scene she created as a woman in the second half of the 19th century espousing anarchy for the purpose of overthrowing capitalism. An African-American born into slavery, Parsons grew up to fashion a story about herself, claiming to be the daughter of Mexican and Native American parents. In her new biography, “Goddess of Anarchy,” Jacqueline Jones writes that Parsons “rejected a personal historical or ethnic identity in favor of presenting herself as the champion of the laboring classes; that, she thought, was all that people needed to know about her.” Ms. Jones, who won the Bancroft Prize in 1986 for her book “Labor of Love, Labor of Sorrow: Black Women, Work, and the Family, from Slavery to the Present,” teaches in the history department at the University of Texas at Austin. Below, she talks about the new information she unearthed about Parsons, the way Parsons captivated crowds and much more.

headline: How a Reporter and Victims’ Families Went ‘Beyond the Horror’ of 2 Kansas Hate Crimes
text: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

headline: Partisans, Wielding Money, Begin Seeking to Exploit Harassment Claims
text: WASHINGTON — As the #MeToo movement to expose sexual harassment roils the nation’s capital, political partisans are exploiting the moment, raising hundreds of thousands of dollars to support accusers who come forward with charges against President Trump and members of Congress, even amid questions about their motivation.

headline: The World Celebrates New Year’s Eve
text: In Sydney, rainbow fireworks sparkled off the Harbour Bridge in celebration of Australia’s recent legalization of gay marriage. (Sydney was among the first major cities to celebrate with fireworks at the stroke of midnight.)

headline: How Do You Vote? 50 Million Google Images Give a Clue
text: What vehicle is most strongly associated with Republican voting districts? Extended-cab pickup trucks. For Democratic districts? Sedans.

headline: Democrats in High-Tax States Plot to Blunt Impact of New Tax Law
text: Democrats in high-cost, high-tax states are plotting ways to do what their states’ representatives in Congress could not: blunt the impact of the newly passed Republican tax overhaul.

headline: On the Way to the Doctor
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Torch Song Pentalogy
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Some of you will be reading this before the New Year, and some of you will be reading this when it’s 2018. This post is always tricky to pin down for everyone, so let me pre-emptively and retroactively wish you all a Happy New Year. I hope that no matter how you plan to or did celebrate, fun will be or was had by all, at the time it was actually had.

headline: Courts Must Better Police Themselves on Harassment, Chief Justice Says
text: WASHINGTON — Responding to the retirement of a prominent appeals court judge accused of sexual harassment, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said the federal court system must do more to protect law clerks and other employees from abusive conduct.

headline: Fatal ‘Swatting’ Episode in Kansas Raises Quandary: Who Is to Blame?
text: When the police surrounded a house in Wichita, Kan., late Thursday, they expected to find a gunman who told a 911 dispatcher that he was holding his mother and brother at gunpoint after shooting his father in the head.
